headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to Newfield Exploration's First Quarter 2010 Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] And before we get started, one housekeeping matter.Our discussion with you today will contain forward-looking statements such as estima
componenttext:
Good day, everyone, and welcome to Newfield Exploration's First Quarter 2010 Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] And before we get started, one housekeeping matter.
Our discussion with you today will contain forward-looking statements such as estimated product and timing, drilling and development plans, expected cost reductions and planned capital expenditures. Although we believe that the expectations reflected in these statements are reasonable, they are based upon assumptions and anticipated results that are subject to numerous uncertainties and risks. Please see Newfield's annual report on Form 10-K and quarterly reports on Form 10-Q for a discussion of factors that may cause actual results to vary. In addition, reconciliations of non-GAAP financial measures to GAAP financial measures, together with Newfield's earnings release and any other applicable disclosures, are available on the Investor Relations page of Newfield's website at www.newfld.com.
At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to the President and Chief Executive Officer, Mr. Lee Boothby. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, operator, and good morning. Good morning, everyone. Thanks for dialing in this morning. We certainly appreciate your interest and investment in our company. With me today here in Houston, I have Gary Packer, our Chief Operating Officer; Terry R
componenttext:
Thank you, operator, and good morning. Good morning, everyone. Thanks for dialing in this morning. We certainly appreciate your interest and investment in our company. With me today here in Houston, I have Gary Packer, our Chief Operating Officer; Terry Rathert, our Chief Financial Officer; John Jasek, our Vice President, Gulf of Mexico; Bill Schneider, Vice President of Gulf Coast International; Brian Rickmers, our Controller; and of course, Steve Campbell, Investor Relations; and remotely, we've got George Dunn, our Mid-Continent Region out of Tulsa; and Daryll Howard, who runs our Rockies operation out of Denver, is actually calling in today from Utah. 
On Monday, we published the detailed operations report. This release carried lots of information about each of our focus areas. But more importantly, we announced a reallocation of our capital budget to allow for increased investments in all the projects in 2010. Newfield has real oil projects in its portfolio today, delivering real results. These projects are meaningful and offer us the ability to combine production growth and profitability. There are benefits to a diverse portfolio, and we fully intend to continue using these to our advantage to deliver value to our shareholders. Let me briefly summarize the most significant steps we are taking.
We plan to invest $700 million or about 45% of our 2010 budget on oil projects. These are projects we have in hand today. Keep in mind, our initial shift to oil actually began months ago as we accelerated development drilling in Malaysia, added rigs in Monument Butte and the Williston Basin at year end and significantly increased our natural gas hedges to protect returns. You are seeing the benefits of these positions in our guidance today. 
Second, we expect our domestic oil volumes to grow about 20% in 2010, with the most significant drivers being Monument Butte, Malaysia and the Williston Basin. I'll spend more time on this call discussing our improved outlook for Monument Butte growth. 
Third, our foundational gas assets are held by production and give us great flexibility in our investment timing. We plan to reduce our active rig count in the Woodford from the current pace of eight rigs to a 2010 exit of around four to five rigs. With continued great results from our Super Extended Laterals, we still expect that Woodford production should grow 20% in 2010. So when you combine all of the above, we expect that our production for 2010 will be more oily and will land in the upper half of our beginning-of-year guidance. We expect to grow at least 10% in 2010.
Last night, we published our first quarter financial results. From a financial reporting standpoint, it was a very simple quarter. Pre-FAS 133, we earned $1.19 per share, surpassing First Call estimates due primarily to lower operating expenses in the quarter. In yesterday's earnings release, we provided enhanced guidance for the remainder of the year, showing our second quarter expectations, as well as full year expectation for various metrics helpful in your modeling and analysis. As always, we'll be happy to take your questions at the end of the call.
The call today will be very brief, and our comments will be focused around three main topics. First, the benefits of a diverse portfolio. Although there are times that it would be fashionable to be 100% gas or 100% oil, we think that having a diverse and balanced portfolio to invest in at the appropriate times is the best formula to create long-term value. Second, I want to spotlight our in-hand oil projects that will drive top-tier production growth within cash flow in 2010 and 2011. The cornerstone of this program is Monument Butte, and the recent results from our Rockies teams are excellent. And finally, I'll quickly cover our planned activities in the new exploration areas that we are hopeful could become a play of the future for Newfield.
Many of you have visited our headquarters and regional offices and have seen our founding business principles prominently displayed in our lobbies. We talked often about these, and they are ingrained in our DNA. One of those principles is balance. And to us, that means a lot of things: balance between exploration and development, between onshore and offshore, conventional and unconventional. But perhaps the most important today is a balance between oil assets and gas assets. This is a great time to have oil opportunities to invest in. 
For some time, we've had a view that oil was good, and that we needed a solid representation in oil plays, both in the U.S. and in Southeast Asia. In 2004, we took two large steps on our path to transforming Newfield. We entered the shallow water arena in Malaysia, and we acquired the giant Monument Butte field in Utah. The time the Monument Butte acquisition, the field was producing about 7,000 barrels a day, and oil was about $30 per barrel. Today, both field production and oil prices have nearly tripled. This was a great acquisition and is the cornerstone of our domestic oil production growth. 
We're investing more in our oil projects today because it's the right economic choice. We're able to slower growth in gas developments and accelerate our oil plays. Our 2010 domestic oil production is now expected to grow about 20% over 2009 volumes. Because we are shifting more investments to oil early in the year, this will have a positive impact on our 2011 oil volumes as well. 
We have the flexibility to shift capital today because we have a very limited drilling obligations to hold our acreage and our gas plays. In the Woodford and Granite Wash plays, substantially all our acreage is held by production. Simply running one rig in the Woodford in 2010 and 2011 will keep us from losing any acreage. We're in a great position to let economics guide our drilling decisions, not lease expirations. Let's talk about the oil assets that are contributing to our growth today.
Monument Butte. What a great asset. We recently set a production record at the Monument Butte field of just under 20,000 barrels per day. 19,900 barrels, to be specific. That's up nearly 3,000 barrels a day since year-end 2009. We are combining improved drilling performance and higher production rates from recent wells drilled on our Ute Tribal acreage. We now estimate that our Monument Butte production will grow 20% in 2010, stronger than our beginning-of-year guidance of 15%. We talk often about Monument Butte, and one of the most common questions has been why can't you grow production at a faster pace. Well, today, we can. There's an increased demand for Black Wax from area refiners, and refining capacity expansions allow for more production. We comprise more than 50% of the Black Wax capacity in the region and are clearly the one capable of sizable future growth. Our 2010 production is sold under term sales, and 87% of our 2011 production is now termed. Current differentials are about $13 below NYMEX and remember, that includes around $6 of transportation expense.
Along with good demand, we have exemplary drilling performance in the field. Our drilling personnel are setting new records in days to depth. We recently drilled a well in three and a half days. Year-to-date, we are averaging four and a half days compared to a 2009 average of five and a half days. Today, our five-rig program is the efficient equivalent of running eight rigs back in 2006. We call these incremental rigs, virtual rigs, and their impact is showing up in our volumes today. We now expect that a five-rig program will allow us to drill more than 350 wells in 2010, up from earlier expectations of 275. An average well here costs about $800,000 to drill and complete. Monument Butte field level production is expected to exit 2010 at about 25,000 barrels of oil per day, and we expect to have very strong oil growth here in 2011 as well.
Our results in the Ute Tribal acreage continue to exceed original expectations, with higher early production rates and good drilling performance. This area covers 63,000 net acres immediately north and adjacent to our Monument Butte field. Over the last two years, we've drilled more than 125 wells in this acreage and are quickly assessing its potential. We believe we have more than 1,000 development locations in front of us on this acreage at 40-acre spacing and double that if the fields ultimately develop on 20s, like Monument Butte properties is today. Our interests on the Ute Tribal acreage runs about 70%. In total, we estimate there are approximately 4,700 development drilling locations remaining in the Monument Butte field area. 
Moving on to the Williston Basin, this is our second largest growth region in the Rockies where we have about 400,000 net acres, about half of which is currently in active development or appraisal. In our operations released Monday, we provided results from several recent development wells in our Westberg and Lost Bear development areas along the Nesson Anticline. Recent wells include our highest initial production rates achieved to date. 
Our Williston Basin production is expected to increase at least 40% in 2010. Our two most recent wells had initial production of more than 3,300 barrels of oil per day and a 30-day average production of more than 1,100 barrels of oil per day. Our team is clearly lining, and we have optimized our drilling and completion operations. We expect to drill 30 to 35 wells in the Williston Basin in 2010 and may elect to add an additional rig here later in the year. 
We have approximately 100,000 acres that are located west of the Nesson Anticline. To date, we've drilled three successful wells here, and they are online and producing today. We are encouraged by their success and plan to drill additional wells in these areas in 2010. Industry successes around our acreage provide encouragement, and we hope to have a more thorough update for you later this year.
Moving on now to Malaysia. This is one of our major oil-producing regions. We are benefiting today from investments made over the last several years to develop shallow water oil fields. In April, our productions had a gross record of 45,000 barrels of oil per day and which translates to about 20,000 barrels a day, net. The recent increase is due to higher-than-planned production volumes from the operated development at East Belumut and Chermingat, both located in the shallow water block PM 323. The increase has not happened since. 
In the second half of 2009, we accelerated by six months the timing of six planned development wells at East Belumut. Because of better drilling performance, we were able to drill a total of seven development wells during the time allotted for the rig and for the same budgeted amount for the original six wells in the program. This moved our East Belumut production to more than 24,000 barrels of oil per day gross, and we expect to maintain this level throughout the year. And importantly, we're utilizing our horizontal drilling and completions expertise internationally as well. 
So the bottom line is this: We had originally estimated Malaysia would decline in 2010 by about 18% due to natural field depletion. Our improved performance at East Belumut reduces this decline to less than half this amount. This is a great time to have the extra oil production coming out of Southeast Asia, and hats off to our team there who's doing a great job. 
Emphasis on the future. I'll remind you that we've added more than 500,000 net acres in domestic resource plays in the fourth quarter of '09, now through the early portion of 2010. It's important that we not lose sight of the future and that we continue to invest in plays that have a chance to be the next Monument Butte field or the next Woodford Shale. These are our plays of the future. 
The Maverick Basin. Important asset. We entered here earlier this year and closed an acquisition that brought to us more than 300,000 prospective net acres in Maverick and Dimmit Counties. We're very encouraged by the potential of our acreage and believe it will prove to be analogous to recent success being reported elsewhere in the play. We have a very thorough evaluation plan, and we'll know a lot more in late 2010. 
Beginning in June, we'll begin a multi-rig program to assess the Eagle Ford and Pearsall Shale formations, as well as other oil formations that are in perspective across the acreage. We plan to invest more than $100 million to drill about 25 wells in 2010 to assess the newly acquired acreage. We plan to test the Eagle Ford formation at multiple depths perspective for both gas and oil. Recent successes around us provide early encouragement as to the potential on our acreage, and we look forward to reporting on our progress later this year.
Moving north to the Southern Alberta Basin, we captured about 224,000 net acres of what we think is an area that has a potential to be a Williston Basin and Bakken look-alike. Our prospective formations of the Lodgepole, Middle Bakken, Sanish and the deeper Nisku. We spud our first well in a few days, waiting on a rig and expect to drill approximately eight wells here in the second half of the year. Depending on success, our activity levels here could be expanded in late 2010 or 2011. 
It is important that we also work to maintain a momentum in our gas plays. In the Monday operations release, we provided a good update on our foundational gas assets in the Mid-Continent, the Woodford Shale and the Granite Wash plays. We continue to drill Super Extended Laterals in the Woodford with lateral lines of about 9,000 feet and initial production rates averaging 9 million cubic feet per day. We are reducing our planned investments in the Woodford to allow for reallocation of capital to the oil plays we outlined moments ago. Despite the reduction in planned development drilling and capital, we still expect the Woodford Shale to grow 20% in 2010. In the Granite Wash, we continue to have excellent results on this play, and our current phase of four rigs will continue through the rest of 2010. More than half of our planned wells in the remainder of the year will be in the condensate-rich formations in the Granite Wash.
It's important also that we maintain healthy activity levels on our gas plays, but growth for growth's sake is not good business and certainly not Newfield business, particularly given the fact that we have alternative wall investments with better returns in today's market. But good momentum in our gas plays keeps our team sharp, constantly striving for new efficiency gains. We will continue to reap these benefits. There will come a time when increased investments in growth and gas plays are wanted economically, and Newfield will remain in a position to instantly ramp up our activities. 
As promised, we kept today's call short. This concludes our prepared remarks. We're happy to take your questions at this time.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Dave Kistler with Simmons & Company.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Dave Kistler with Simmons & Company.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Wanted to touch on one thing you mentioned on the acreage that's held by production. Can you walk through the other areas outside of the Woodford, what is held, what is its expiry timing and then plans for drilling that to hold?
componenttext: Wanted to touch on one thing you mentioned on the acreage that's held by production. Can you walk through the other areas outside of the Woodford, what is held, what is its expiry timing and then plans for drilling that to hold?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll turn that over to Gary.
componenttext: Yes, I'll turn that over to Gary.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Just quickly if we walk around the various bits and positions [ph] (30:54) and since we move outside the Woodford, the Granite Wash is essentially all HBP, very minimal requirements as we go there. As we move in to the Rocky Mountains, Monument Butte is e
componenttext: Just quickly if we walk around the various bits and positions [ph] (30:54) and since we move outside the Woodford, the Granite Wash is essentially all HBP, very minimal requirements as we go there. As we move in to the Rocky Mountains, Monument Butte is essentially all HBP. And the agreements that we have with the Ute Indian Tribe and our various joint ventures have very reasonable requirements that we're far ahead of exceeding. So there's no HBP issues there. As we step out of there into the Williston Basin, we have quite a bit term on our Southern Alberta positions there, on a majority of that acreage. So let's just say we're in probably a three- to five-year zip code on the majority of that. As we step over into the Williston Basin, that's the area that -- if there is an area that we need to make sure that we keep a healthy level of activity up to hold our acreage position, it would be there. Certainly, it's opportunistic at this time with oil prices where they are and elevating activity, we're able to hold our acreage position there on all of the appraisal and development areas. And that's typically in this three- to five-rig program. We see no issues there. Onshore, in the Maverick Basin, we have the $100 million investment that we have scheduled there this year. And our plans forward meet all of the requirements that we have for any lease maintenance issues there. So overall, we're sitting very comfortable with where we're at right now, and it really lends itself to our ability to allocate capital back and forth between areas.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: And, Dave, we've been very careful as we added the projects and the 500,000 net acres that I talked about in the call. We've been very careful to look at those projects and make sure that we could absorb those into our investment portfolio, keeping in min
componenttext: And, Dave, we've been very careful as we added the projects and the 500,000 net acres that I talked about in the call. We've been very careful to look at those projects and make sure that we could absorb those into our investment portfolio, keeping in mind our commitment to limiting cash flow. So we're very comfortable with our ability to execute in each of those areas and really glad to have the acreage position that we have.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Hopping to Monument Butte, can you talk a little bit about maybe the geologic differences that we're seeing in between the Ute Tribal acreage and your Monument Butte acreage that you still hold, but it's the kind of core steps we've had. It looks like you
componenttext: Hopping to Monument Butte, can you talk a little bit about maybe the geologic differences that we're seeing in between the Ute Tribal acreage and your Monument Butte acreage that you still hold, but it's the kind of core steps we've had. It looks like yours are a little higher or could be a little higher out of the Ute Tribal area. Any kind of color on that would be great. And then as a follow-up on that, if you could walk through kind of the step shift change and the drilling efficiencies that took place in this last year from 5.5 days to four and a half days.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, since Gary hasn't gotten the Rockies out of his bloodstream, I'm going to go ahead and let him talk about that.
componenttext: Well, since Gary hasn't gotten the Rockies out of his bloodstream, I'm going to go ahead and let him talk about that.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: As far as the EURs go and the formations that we're exploring out there, we drilled about 125 wells. And those wells primarily target the same Green River formations that we're playing in Monument Butte. They're a little deeper. Despite being a little thi
componenttext: As far as the EURs go and the formations that we're exploring out there, we drilled about 125 wells. And those wells primarily target the same Green River formations that we're playing in Monument Butte. They're a little deeper. Despite being a little thinner overall, we're seeing good pressure in the formations. And they appear to be a little bit better fractured than we see at the South, and we're actually seeing the benefits of that in our EURs. As far as the drilling efficiencies, it's pretty remarkable. And it's really some of the benefits we've realized by moving people around the organization. We made some changes earlier this year, some of the brave folks that came out of the Woodford went into the Rockies and working with our teams there. We've made mechanical enhancements to the rigs that we're employing there. We've added electronic monitoring of all our drilling parameters, consistent with maybe some of the more higher-tech rigs or offshore rigs. By having all this data available to it, we're analyzing it, and we've installed auto drillers in all the rigs. And we're able to maintain very precise drilling requirements on weight on bit, rotary speed, differential pressures, things like that. As a result of those small steps, we're seeing remarkable changes in the drilling efficiency. In combination with that, we further advanced working with some of the bit designers, some customized PDC bits that really performing quite well in these areas. And when we talk about these changes, you referenced, Dave, over the last year, I can tell you it's probably over the last three months we're seeing these changes.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, following up on that a little bit, not just the efficiencies but also on the recovery, the progress you're seeing on the drill bit side, fantastic. If we think about it from the recovery side, are we seeing that same step change in terms of completi
componenttext: Well, following up on that a little bit, not just the efficiencies but also on the recovery, the progress you're seeing on the drill bit side, fantastic. If we think about it from the recovery side, are we seeing that same step change in terms of completion technology and what that's ultimately doing. Are there any incremental developments we should be thinking about or starting to model in on that side?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: I wouldn't say -- when we think about the step changes that Newfield's realized in the last quarter or so on completions, I would say it's mostly on the horizontal completion efficiencies and recoveries that we're seeing in both the Woodford and the Willi
componenttext: I wouldn't say -- when we think about the step changes that Newfield's realized in the last quarter or so on completions, I would say it's mostly on the horizontal completion efficiencies and recoveries that we're seeing in both the Woodford and the Williston Basin, some really interesting and exciting stuff going on there. In the Monument Butte area, I'd say our completions really haven't altered too much. And I wouldn't really attribute any change in EURs [estimate ultimate recovery] to that.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Dave, I would remind you that when you think about these large plays, we've seen a really good progression based on learning curves. Gary's point that moving people around between the business units and the focus that we've had on optionality in the portf
componenttext: Dave, I would remind you that when you think about these large plays, we've seen a really good progression based on learning curves. Gary's point that moving people around between the business units and the focus that we've had on optionality in the portfolio in gas versus oil and the fact that we've been on that hunt for a year and a half now across the organization, there are a lot of gains everywhere because our people are walking and working across geographic boundaries, sharing information that's much more timely, knowledge transfer. Clearly, a portion of our performance is probably tied up in completion gains, normal learning. But back to your earlier question in terms of Ute Tribal versus Monument Butte proper, we don't know absolutely why we're getting better results on average, but three of our five rigs are working on the Ute Tribal acreage. And that's not an accident. So we're excited about what we're seeing, and we're going keep pressing it. And I think it's just fantastic results that our team is delivering, and it's a testament to the quality of the folks that we have in the organization.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Just looking at the hedges you guys put in place. You've got gas now, a portion of it small relative, but hedged out to 2013 and oil hedged out to 2012. Obviously, your longer-term hedges have served you well in this downturn. Can you just talk a little b
componenttext: Just looking at the hedges you guys put in place. You've got gas now, a portion of it small relative, but hedged out to 2013 and oil hedged out to 2012. Obviously, your longer-term hedges have served you well in this downturn. Can you just talk a little bit about philosophy for hedging of three-plus years out?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Dave, I think the idea here is to make sure that we have a certain band of downside protection as we go out there. Clearly we're, I think, anxious about the midterm for natural gas. We've seen, in other operators as well as ourselves, continued drilling e
componenttext: Dave, I think the idea here is to make sure that we have a certain band of downside protection as we go out there. Clearly we're, I think, anxious about the midterm for natural gas. We've seen, in other operators as well as ourselves, continued drilling efficiencies we've been talking about all morning, and what that means is lower and lower cost to develop reserves in these large resource spaces. That just signals to me that we could be in a commodity price environment that isn't very robust, and the forward curve gives us the opportunity to put some positions in place that begin to assure cash flow in those periods of time, which we know we can maintain a level of activity, continue to underpin growth. So philosophically, we're still I'd say predominantly 18 to 24 month horizon hedgers with 1/3 of our production in the market, 1/3 with a fixed price and 1/3, some type of a floor. So we can participate in 2/3 the upside and protect against 2/3 downside. When we think a little bit further out, it's really just starting to feather in some prices that we believe were probably attractive in that mid-term period.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from David Tameron with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Our next question comes from David Tameron with Wells Fargo.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Just building on Monument Butte. If you have three to five rigs now running on the Ute Tribal acreage, does that give you the ability to add another, I guess, legacy Monument Butte?
componenttext: Just building on Monument Butte. If you have three to five rigs now running on the Ute Tribal acreage, does that give you the ability to add another, I guess, legacy Monument Butte?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: David, I think the way you ought to think about that is kind of some of the things that Lee included in his earlier call. At historical rate, last year, at five rigs, we're drilling at the equivalent at that pace of a seven- or eight-rig program today. As
componenttext: David, I think the way you ought to think about that is kind of some of the things that Lee included in his earlier call. At historical rate, last year, at five rigs, we're drilling at the equivalent at that pace of a seven- or eight-rig program today. As you're well aware, historically, our limitations there have been in overall permits. We believe that we're able to navigate to a seven- and eight-rig equivalent program because of the permitting structure of the DIA and working with Ute Indian tribes. As we reallocate our monies and continue to optimize that, we will attempt to put another real rig in Monument Butte, which could put us in the equivalent eight- to nine-rig level relative to historical numbers. But we have to monitor that real carefully. With these changes that we've seen year-to-date, we need to make sure that all the regulatory bodies can keep up with us. And once we're comfortable that we can accommodate that, we'll look to actually put another rig in the year out of Monument Butte.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: And Gary, last quarter, you guys have talked about doing a step out that came on north of 1,000 barrels a day. Have you guys seen anything close to that in some of the more recent wells? Or can you give us any indication where your production's tracking o
componenttext: And Gary, last quarter, you guys have talked about doing a step out that came on north of 1,000 barrels a day. Have you guys seen anything close to that in some of the more recent wells? Or can you give us any indication where your production's tracking on those?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: I've got to be careful. We'll be talking about too much about some of these -- the activity [ph] (40:43). But I will say that we're seeing -- we've drilled a handful of about step-out wells in the area. I think certainly the thousand barrel a day is an an
componenttext: I've got to be careful. We'll be talking about too much about some of these -- the activity [ph] (40:43). But I will say that we're seeing -- we've drilled a handful of about step-out wells in the area. I think certainly the thousand barrel a day is an anomaly. I think there was a competitor that stepped out and drilled and announced a well that had similar rates to that, and so it just allows us to be opportunistic of what's out in front of us. I think if you looked at our acreage position, David, between fee acreage and the tribal acreage right now, we're sitting on about 75,000 acres north of Monument Butte proper.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: And then in the Eagleford. Can you talk about what you guys are targeting as far as -- there's obviously a lot of uncertainly about oil versus gas, window versus conden [condensate], condensate versus NGL [natural gas liquids] versus gas, et cetera, et ce
componenttext: And then in the Eagleford. Can you talk about what you guys are targeting as far as -- there's obviously a lot of uncertainly about oil versus gas, window versus conden [condensate], condensate versus NGL [natural gas liquids] versus gas, et cetera, et cetera. Can you talk about what you guys are targeting, where you think you are at as far as the window goes in -- just give us some more color.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: I'll go ahead and take the first part of that, David. Then Bill Schneider's here is if he's got any additional color, I'll let him jump in on the back end. We've described the Maverick Basin assets that we've acquired as having representation across the e
componenttext: I'll go ahead and take the first part of that, David. Then Bill Schneider's here is if he's got any additional color, I'll let him jump in on the back end. We've described the Maverick Basin assets that we've acquired as having representation across the entirety of the phase on below from dry gas to the wet gas condensate and all the way through oil. When we said in the call that our plans are to test the Eagleford at multiple depths and multiple locations, it's to test the entirety of the phase envelope, fluid typing, et cetera across our acreage block. We'll do that during of course the balance of 2010. And frankly, going into 2011, we'll be a lot smarter than we are today. The team's doing a great job, got a great plan. And we're excited about assets. And in the time that we've owned the assets, it's only been a few months now, industry has continue to march in our direction with some pretty impressive rates. So we're excited. But we need to drill some new field wells and get some new field data, and when we have it, we'll give you guys more information. Bill, you have anything else to add?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: No, we'll be testing both the lower Eagleford and the upper Eagleford in various positions across the acreage to see about the prospectivity in each of those formations.
componenttext: No, we'll be testing both the lower Eagleford and the upper Eagleford in various positions across the acreage to see about the prospectivity in each of those formations.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: As you look across, are you guys looking to build acreage anywhere as you see some of these HBP issues happen elsewhere in the industry, are you looking to be -- obviously, everyone's always looking to be opportunistic. But are you guys looking specifical
componenttext: As you look across, are you guys looking to build acreage anywhere as you see some of these HBP issues happen elsewhere in the industry, are you looking to be -- obviously, everyone's always looking to be opportunistic. But are you guys looking specifically anywhere to jump in at bolt ons?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: I guess, David, tongue-in-cheek, if we were, I wouldn't tell you for obvious reasons. We are going to be opportunistic for obvious reasons. I think our position that we have leaves us very comfortable. We're not under stress or duress but 500,000 net acre
componenttext: I guess, David, tongue-in-cheek, if we were, I wouldn't tell you for obvious reasons. We are going to be opportunistic for obvious reasons. I think our position that we have leaves us very comfortable. We're not under stress or duress but 500,000 net acre adds is a lot to digest. I think we've got our team pretty well allocated. The ability to shift quarter-over-quarter $200 million of capital to oil, I don't think there are a lot of organizations that could do that efficiently and effectively. So we're going to be sensitive to what we've got going on with the overall business strategy on the ground. But yes, you can count on Newfield continuing to be opportunistic as we move into the future.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Michael Jacobs with Tudor, Pickering.
componenttext: The next question comes from Michael Jacobs with Tudor, Pickering.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Two questions this morning. One on the Monument Butte, and one on the Woodford. In the Butte, just really nice ramp especially when I kind of think ahead to 2011 implications. And you mentioned on the call, you've got all your production hedged this year,
componenttext: Two questions this morning. One on the Monument Butte, and one on the Woodford. In the Butte, just really nice ramp especially when I kind of think ahead to 2011 implications. And you mentioned on the call, you've got all your production hedged this year, most of it next year. When you think about the trajectory of your growth in that area and your position, are you seeing more competitive pricing from refiners who may want to lock in those volumes longer term?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, the first thing, if I did say, I didn't mean to. But I don't think I said that we had everything hedged. What we have is all of our production out of that region under term contracts, which tells you that we've got the ability to move it to the refi
componenttext: Well, the first thing, if I did say, I didn't mean to. But I don't think I said that we had everything hedged. What we have is all of our production out of that region under term contracts, which tells you that we've got the ability to move it to the refineries and to market 100% of our volumes in 2010. And I think the number's 87% to 2011. I'll let Gary handle the rest of your question.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: At this point, we're not seeing any change in the differentials that we've historically seen. We're not blocked that many years out forward as we just alluded. We're just locked in on 2011. We're still seeing somewhere a $12 or $13 differential. I think w
componenttext: At this point, we're not seeing any change in the differentials that we've historically seen. We're not blocked that many years out forward as we just alluded. We're just locked in on 2011. We're still seeing somewhere a $12 or $13 differential. I think we'll examine the markets as we move forward, and we'll make sure that they remain competitive with what our other options are in the area. But at this point, we're not seeing any change in that differential.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: On the Woodford, just thinking about your drilling campaign over the last few years as you're moving to hold all your acreage, can you give us a little bit of background as to how many locations with respect to -- I think you've given a 300-well number th
componenttext: On the Woodford, just thinking about your drilling campaign over the last few years as you're moving to hold all your acreage, can you give us a little bit of background as to how many locations with respect to -- I think you've given a 300-well number that had been drilled to hold. How many locations have you booked or perhaps your booking methodology? And then maybe a little bit of color as to the evolution of those locations as you move towards drilling longer laterals and how those bookings play out.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, first of all, I guess, let me process it with -- in our Form 10-K, we've been pretty transparent about the probable and possible numbers. As you're well aware...
componenttext: Well, first of all, I guess, let me process it with -- in our Form 10-K, we've been pretty transparent about the probable and possible numbers. As you're well aware...

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: [indiscernible] (46:40) proved and probable...
componenttext: [indiscernible] (46:40) proved and probable...

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Proved and probable. As you're well aware, we're the only company that's come out to my knowledge domestically and put our probable numbers out there in our financial reports. Part of the reasons we did that was to allow transparency in how we moved reser
componenttext: Proved and probable. As you're well aware, we're the only company that's come out to my knowledge domestically and put our probable numbers out there in our financial reports. Part of the reasons we did that was to allow transparency in how we moved reserves between proved and probable as our activity shifted between areas. And I think this year is a perfect example as we see ourselves reallocating capital from gas to oil. What you will see is really no change in the overall 2P number other than what we add externally through the projects. And because of the five-year PUD rule, you'll see areas that were historically gas could back off on a proved basis, but stay whole on a 2P basis on which in the oil areas such as Monument Butte and others, you ought to see that same increase associated there and sort of redeploy the capital. All in all, it ought to be an NAV proved basis increase as we move more to oil and less out of gas. I guess coming back to your original question as it relates to the Mid-Continent, as you're probably aware -- and your numbers are in the right zip code, probably a little over 300 wells originally in there on a proved basis. I think it's safe to say that we have a similar number of wells that are technically proved that are actually sitting out there in probable just because of the PUD rule. So there ought to be, for the investment community, a high degree of confidence in the numbers that we see and are very comfortable with technically proved in the Woodford Shale. And we'll just see a little bit of noise that we've been very transparent in as we allocate monies back and forth between those.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Gary, just kind of follow-up to that, there is a high degree of confidence on the reserve numbers. What I was specifically alluding to was the capital associated. And conceptually, as you drill longer and longer laterals and your F&Ds [finding and develop
componenttext: Gary, just kind of follow-up to that, there is a high degree of confidence on the reserve numbers. What I was specifically alluding to was the capital associated. And conceptually, as you drill longer and longer laterals and your F&Ds [finding and development] improve, I'm just wondering how much of that is reflected in the proved case. And so some breakout of kind of longer laterals versus shorter laterals than the unbooked case would be helpful as well as any potential upside to you're proved case as you get more data from drilling longer laterals in your reserve, others allow you to take up those reserves.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Mike. I think probably the best answer I can give you and I don't [ph] (49:20) understand what you're chasing. And we've been very careful to try keep people from getting focused on individual well accounts or individual well types. And you can look
componenttext: Yes, Mike. I think probably the best answer I can give you and I don't [ph] (49:20) understand what you're chasing. And we've been very careful to try keep people from getting focused on individual well accounts or individual well types. And you can look at the Woodford as a great example at just how much a well has been modified over time. So we think about reserves. Our reserves on the books, I'll remind you that anything that showed up in the 2P reserves at year end 2009 had a $3.87 stress test. That's what I take comfort in, and that's what you ought to be thinking about when you're looking at portfolios. To give you a number, I think the number from memory, in terms of the probable component associated with the Woodford, is a number just over 800 Bs. So that didn't show up in the proved overs. It's just over 800 Bs or somewhere in that zip code. That's about $1.50. And in terms of F&Ds, if that's the way to think about the reserves and the economics, if you follow up with Steve, he can give you some additional color. You can go back to the 10-K. There's a pretty good description, I believe, in their. And on the overall acreage count, as far exposure to super extended laterals, we've talked about 25% to 33% of the acreage depending upon how some of the unit activities work out in Oklahoma, and those numbers still hold today. But I would be very careful with well counts. We can talk to you about reserves, and we'll give you some color on how all that fits together. But that's probably about all we can do today.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Subash Chandra with Jefferies & Company.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Subash Chandra with Jefferies & Company.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Just to follow up I guess on the Monument Butte and some of the probable discussion, how many PUD locations versus new well bookings is part of the 2010 plan? And the second question on Monument Butte is, any particular comingling work being done, and if
componenttext: Just to follow up I guess on the Monument Butte and some of the probable discussion, how many PUD locations versus new well bookings is part of the 2010 plan? And the second question on Monument Butte is, any particular comingling work being done, and if and when? And is it possible to perhaps tap several zones from a single well out there?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Let see. As far as the level of activity in our drilling campaigns, historically, and this number holds true, about 70% of the drilling activity that takes place at Monument Butte is on a PUD location. And about 30% is on a new probable new reserve at typ
componenttext: Let see. As far as the level of activity in our drilling campaigns, historically, and this number holds true, about 70% of the drilling activity that takes place at Monument Butte is on a PUD location. And about 30% is on a new probable new reserve at type [ph] (51:45) location. And we probably have on the order of half a Tcf or so of probable reserves associated with the Rocky Mountains, largely at this point confined to Monument Butte. So I can't give you an exact well count, probable versus others. I believe, if you refer to some of Steve's public releases, we've talked about as many as, now this is on a 3P basis, about 4,700 locations. And generically, we've talked about 1,000 of those being up in the tribal areas on 40s. Now this is very early to talk about spacing and so forth. And the Ute's is pretty premature at this point. On the comingling, I'm not really following the question in that in these vertical wells, we go ahead and we comingle virtually all of the zones. Occasionally, we'll leave some out, and we'll come back in and add them later. But in the Green River formations, the vertical wells, then we typically conduct about five or six comingled fracs on a normal basis. Now occasionally, we'll encounter a Wasatch formation. In those situations, we'll add those to the comingled section.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: So on the probables, I think that 70-30's a helpful split to go by. Then I guess on the Monument Butte, I guess I was really asking if there was some other zones out there that are prospective that have not been produced out of yet for oil.
componenttext: So on the probables, I think that 70-30's a helpful split to go by. Then I guess on the Monument Butte, I guess I was really asking if there was some other zones out there that are prospective that have not been produced out of yet for oil.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we hope there are. We've got a really attractive acreage position. And I'm confident that our team will find them, what [ph] (53:45)they are, Subash. How's that?
componenttext: Well, we hope there are. We've got a really attractive acreage position. And I'm confident that our team will find them, what [ph] (53:45)they are, Subash. How's that?

componenttext: Then at West of Anticline, just curious how many of those three wells were TFS [Three Forks Sanish] or Bakken. I think at least one was TFS, but if there's any additional color...

componenttext: I think you'd mentioned previously that in the oil window or maybe in the condensate window, Eagleford and the over pressured area, Atascosa County or wherever, that you did have a package of 10,000 acres or so.
