componenttext: No, we're going to be participating in a well that will be drilled probably in June to test the oily section of the Eagleford in the Passion Field [ph] (55:00) area.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Next, we'll hear from Brian Singer with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Next, we'll hear from Brian Singer with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: A two part question on how you're thinking about the balance of oil versus gas from here. How much would oil prices need to fall or natural gas prices need to rise from here for you to shift a bit more back into natural gas? And alternatively, if the oil-
componenttext: A two part question on how you're thinking about the balance of oil versus gas from here. How much would oil prices need to fall or natural gas prices need to rise from here for you to shift a bit more back into natural gas? And alternatively, if the oil-to-gas ratio stays at these levels or widens, how much more room, if any, is there to shift additional capital to liquids at the expense of gas?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Brian. That sounds like an IQ test. I'm going to hand that one to Terry Rathert.
componenttext: Yes, Brian. That sounds like an IQ test. I'm going to hand that one to Terry Rathert.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: I think, one of the thing's that's pretty important is, what are the costs associated with that? If we can continue to drive the natural gas cost down in the Woodford and commodity prices change a little bit, then you dramatically change the profitability
componenttext: I think, one of the thing's that's pretty important is, what are the costs associated with that? If we can continue to drive the natural gas cost down in the Woodford and commodity prices change a little bit, then you dramatically change the profitability. So it's a function, not just price but what is the cost. Today, we're seeing a rush to oil patch, literally, of rigs in activity. That could well translate into increased service costs, which would change the margin despite what commodity prices do to bring the two closer to alignment. I think it's a hard question to say what would they need to do, et cetera. But what I can tell you is we look at that almost on a daily, weekly, monthly basis. And the majority of our activity is not term or obligations, but it's options. And we have the ability to in very, very short period of time shift those resources both capital and human resources to the thing that is most profitable. So we look at it on a regular basis. All the activity we talked about this morning I mean it shifted in some $200 million around here in the first couple of months of 2010. We did the same thing last year. If we need to, we can shift it back in a couple of months. We'll just be very opportunistic based upon what the margins are. It's really a margin question as compared to a commodity price question.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Do you feel like you're going to need a 20%, 30%, 50% change in margins to switch back here in the near term or is there some margin guidance that you're looking at on a relative basis of oil versus gas?
componenttext: Do you feel like you're going to need a 20%, 30%, 50% change in margins to switch back here in the near term or is there some margin guidance that you're looking at on a relative basis of oil versus gas?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: We go for the highest margin daily. And if it's 1% better in one place than other, considering the cost of making the change, yes, we're going to go for that 1% more margin because my learnings have been, you take 1% here, 1% there or 2% here and 2% there
componenttext: We go for the highest margin daily. And if it's 1% better in one place than other, considering the cost of making the change, yes, we're going to go for that 1% more margin because my learnings have been, you take 1% here, 1% there or 2% here and 2% there. And you start adding all that up, at the end of time, it makes a huge difference.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: And, Brian, clearly, as everybody well understands today, I mean the whole oil argument is what we would call internally compelling. And the last two years, 2008, 2009, we allocated about 25% our budget to oil projects. You can see the swing in oil versus
componenttext: And, Brian, clearly, as everybody well understands today, I mean the whole oil argument is what we would call internally compelling. And the last two years, 2008, 2009, we allocated about 25% our budget to oil projects. You can see the swing in oil versus gas over the last several months. With the changes that we're making in 2010 that we've discussed, we'll be at 45%. That's a pretty significant year-over-year change in investments to oil. So we've gone from 25% last year to 45% currently planned in 2010, and we did talk about in the call, options to add rigs in the second half of the year. And we'll add those sensitive to all of the issues that we've talked about, living within cash flow, the margin discussion that Gary's just talked about and the operational efficiencies that Gary spent time talking about earlier. We've got to be sensitive to all those factors because adding activity into an area and being inefficient's not a good recipe.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Then secondly on the Williston, you mentioned a few of the individual wells that had a relatively wide range in terms of your working interest. Can you add any more color on differences, if any, in your expectations for well results and geology in the acr
componenttext: Then secondly on the Williston, you mentioned a few of the individual wells that had a relatively wide range in terms of your working interest. Can you add any more color on differences, if any, in your expectations for well results and geology in the acreage that you have a high working interest in versus acreage you have a lower working interest?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Of course, we expect really spectacular results in the high interest and average results on the low. That's a smart ass part of it. So I'll let Gary give you the real answer.
componenttext: Of course, we expect really spectacular results in the high interest and average results on the low. That's a smart ass part of it. So I'll let Gary give you the real answer.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: In general, Brian, I would describe the areas where we have a more modest interests, let's say, in the 30%, 40% ranges typically found the Nesson Anticline where it hits the area that we have that's most mature as far as its development potential. The wel
componenttext: In general, Brian, I would describe the areas where we have a more modest interests, let's say, in the 30%, 40% ranges typically found the Nesson Anticline where it hits the area that we have that's most mature as far as its development potential. The wells referenced, the 3,000-barrel a day wells or so, were in areas that we've probably averaged in that 30%, 40% plus range. As we move west to Nesson, generally, our working interest improves probably on the nature of 50% to 75% working interest when you account the endless areas around you [ph] (1:00:05). And for obvious reasons and as we alluded to in his earlier remarks, it's an area that we have the least understanding. That said, there's some quite a bit of very attractive and exciting industry activity in these areas. So I think in the near term, what you ought to expect from us is a continued success in areas of modest working interest, and as rapidly as we can, shifting to the areas off the Nesson where we have higher working interest. If you give me the latitude to describe the Southern Alberta Basin as a sister to the Williston, in that area there, we're probably -- certainly, high working interest, contiguous positions, 70-plus percent working interest in there. And with success, we can really drive volumes and value there quite rapidly.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Can you give any quick update on Gulf of Mexico exploration?
componenttext: Can you give any quick update on Gulf of Mexico exploration?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: We don't have anything in terms of new information at this point. We've got a couple of wells that are drilling, and we just didn't have the wells down through the objective interval as part of the call. So I would expect that we'll have those results som
componenttext: We don't have anything in terms of new information at this point. We've got a couple of wells that are drilling, and we just didn't have the wells down through the objective interval as part of the call. So I would expect that we'll have those results sometime in May.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Gil Yang with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Gil Yang with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Terry touched on the question of inflation. And maybe I missed it, but could you comment on what inflation you're seeing in different regions that you operate in at the moment?
componenttext: Terry touched on the question of inflation. And maybe I missed it, but could you comment on what inflation you're seeing in different regions that you operate in at the moment?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, it's certainly regionally specific. And as you might imagine, Gil, it's confined at the proximity to some of the highest activity. If we're in the same zip code as the Haynesville Shale, we're  typically seeing higher price and cost pressures. If we
componenttext: Well, it's certainly regionally specific. And as you might imagine, Gil, it's confined at the proximity to some of the highest activity. If we're in the same zip code as the Haynesville Shale, we're  typically seeing higher price and cost pressures. If we're in an area near the Williston Basin, we're seeing those same pressures. Fortunately, in some of the other areas we're active in, we're seeing little or no activity as far as price pressures. As a range, I would say depending on what we're looking at, oil country tubular goods, we're certainly seeing increases there. And outside of our inventory, on the pressure pumping, it's probably anywhere between 5% and 30%. It's probably a good range for you. A portion of that is not just pumping services, pressure pumping being passed along but we're also seeing the impact of increased surcharges as well as profit cost.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Is the competition for, when you're in the same zip code as some of these areas, a function of the fiscal proximity or is there any relationship between -- you're using sort of similar equipment. So Monument Butte, you're using different equipment than in
componenttext: Is the competition for, when you're in the same zip code as some of these areas, a function of the fiscal proximity or is there any relationship between -- you're using sort of similar equipment. So Monument Butte, you're using different equipment than in the Williston Basin. Yes, it's farther, but the bigger issue is that you're using different equipment.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: I think it's probably a combination of both. I mean trucks have wheels, and they can drive down the road pretty easily to redeploy. I think one of the things that we ask all our vendors to really consider is the assets that are being drilled and the susta
componenttext: I think it's probably a combination of both. I mean trucks have wheels, and they can drive down the road pretty easily to redeploy. I think one of the things that we ask all our vendors to really consider is the assets that are being drilled and the sustainability of those programs. We would hate to see one of our prime service providers go chase something that may have a six-month window of opportunity when we plan to be there in drilling for three years to come. So we've had a great deal of success in that. We've got great relationships with our vendors, and they've hung in there through us. And we've hung in there with each other through these dips of activity. So I think it's a combination of both, what you said.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: A question maybe for Gary, but could you remind me what the EURs are for the Monument Butte wells at 40-acre spacing, and what you think they will be at 20-acre spacing?
componenttext: A question maybe for Gary, but could you remind me what the EURs are for the Monument Butte wells at 40-acre spacing, and what you think they will be at 20-acre spacing?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: The question was on 40s and 20s, is that correct?
componenttext: The question was on 40s and 20s, is that correct?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: That's right.
componenttext: That's right.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: We've seen pretty consistent EURs over time there there in the 75 MBOE [MMBOE] per well range. So I wouldn't have any reason to think that, that that's any different. On the 20 acres, I think we're seeing similar numbers, and as we get more and more comfo
componenttext: We've seen pretty consistent EURs over time there there in the 75 MBOE [MMBOE] per well range. So I wouldn't have any reason to think that, that that's any different. On the 20 acres, I think we're seeing similar numbers, and as we get more and more comfortable with the waterflood and how it affects these 20s, I think there's probably opportunities for those numbers to go up rather than down.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: You mean the numbers on the 40s are actually going up or is it on the 20s?
componenttext: You mean the numbers on the 40s are actually going up or is it on the 20s?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: No, the numbers on the 20s are more likely to go up than down. And the numbers on the 40s are consistent at 75 MBO per well.
componenttext: No, the numbers on the 20s are more likely to go up than down. And the numbers on the 40s are consistent at 75 MBO per well.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: So the 20s are a little bit lower than the 75?
componenttext: So the 20s are a little bit lower than the 75?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: No, think of both 40s and 20s as 75 MBO wells. As we gain more and more information, because we're just getting to the point where we're actually converting all the offsets to these 20-acre wells to injectors, as we do that, we're seeing some pretty excit
componenttext: No, think of both 40s and 20s as 75 MBO wells. As we gain more and more information, because we're just getting to the point where we're actually converting all the offsets to these 20-acre wells to injectors, as we do that, we're seeing some pretty exciting performance of these 20s, which would have the opportunity to put upward pressure on the 75 for [ph] (1:05:30). So I'm excited about what we're seeing there, but it's really too early.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Does that suggest that maybe -- could you actually go to like 10-acre spacing?
componenttext: Does that suggest that maybe -- could you actually go to like 10-acre spacing?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: That's a great question, and that's certainly a possibility...
componenttext: That's a great question, and that's certainly a possibility...

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: We're watching it [ph] (1:05:45) ...
componenttext: We're watching it [ph] (1:05:45) ...

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's going to be a matter of commodity prices and margins at the time like many for in-field programs. There's probably areas that will work at 10 acres, and those numbers get awfully big if that's where we go.
componenttext: Yes, it's going to be a matter of commodity prices and margins at the time like many for in-field programs. There's probably areas that will work at 10 acres, and those numbers get awfully big if that's where we go.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: And Gil, I think it's a really good question, and I'm glad you asked it and Gary had the chance to walk you through it. But what I think about Monument Butte, the 75 MBO with all the data that we've got, hundreds, well over a thousand producing wells, 12,
componenttext: And Gil, I think it's a really good question, and I'm glad you asked it and Gary had the chance to walk you through it. But what I think about Monument Butte, the 75 MBO with all the data that we've got, hundreds, well over a thousand producing wells, 12,000, 13 000 producing wells, lots of data, lots of information, you can sleep good at night with that. But we're not injecting water out there for sport. And the secondary waterflood response, the things we're seeing early on are exciting. 75's a safe assumption. The fact that Gary's telling me that there's upside from there, he's just telling me that we're not far enough along to tell you exactly what that looks like. But 75's good, and 75 times 4,000, 5,000 locations gets to a big number. The 10-acre question, yes, it's out there. And our people are all over it. And where does it stop? It'll be all about Terry's margin discussion that we had earlier. So we're excited about the Monument Butte asset. I think it's been, for a long time, an underappreciated part of the Newfield portfolio. The fact that we're able to show that we can drive production growth today, I don't think that'll be lost and that you guys [ph] (1:07:10) and we're going to keep the foot on the accelerator and hopefully the accelerator on the floor.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: The last question, if I may, about Gulf of Mexico. Is there any indication here of what's going to happen after the Transocean disaster in terms of making it more difficult to drill there?
componenttext: The last question, if I may, about Gulf of Mexico. Is there any indication here of what's going to happen after the Transocean disaster in terms of making it more difficult to drill there?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: No. We don't have any knowledge or anything to comment on that, Gil. We'll just have to let that work through with all the appropriate parties, and we'll all get informed at the same time.
componenttext: No. We don't have any knowledge or anything to comment on that, Gil. We'll just have to let that work through with all the appropriate parties, and we'll all get informed at the same time.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Irene Haas with Canaccord.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Irene Haas with Canaccord.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Firstly, back to Monument Butte. I mean right now deep gas is out of favor, but have you guys gotten any sort of update as to what potential you're looking at? I think at one point, you're talking about 2 Tcf. Could you potentially have Pinedale? At some
componenttext: Firstly, back to Monument Butte. I mean right now deep gas is out of favor, but have you guys gotten any sort of update as to what potential you're looking at? I think at one point, you're talking about 2 Tcf. Could you potentially have Pinedale? At some point, gas prices will recover as such, so that's question number one. Question number two has to do with South Alberta Basin. The Bakken play, in my view, is a little bit twin basin [ph] (1:08:10) versus Williston. It's a little shallower and close to the thrust belt. And my question for you is do you expect this structuring to impact how you would attack the Bakken play, number one? Number two, are there any conventional traps within the South Alberta Basin?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: I'll grab the first one and let Gary think about all the questions you asked him, the Southern Alberta Basin and hand it to him I guess after I finish talking. As far as the Monument Butte deep gas, yes, we're still excited about it. We've got half a doze
componenttext: I'll grab the first one and let Gary think about all the questions you asked him, the Southern Alberta Basin and hand it to him I guess after I finish talking. As far as the Monument Butte deep gas, yes, we're still excited about it. We've got half a dozen wells out there producing in the deep section. We proved that there's over 10,000 feet of gas saturated [ph] (1:08:50) section below the Green River oil sands. The vertical production we've seen in that area, out of those wells, exceed anything we were able to do in the early days of Stiles/Britt Ranch out in the Granite Wash play for a point of reference. So we're very excited about the potential there. And we've described it, without putting an absolute number on it, we said it's a multi-Tcf potential. It's in inventory, and the best part of it, it's held by production. So we have no compelling need to drill the well in 2010. And with our shift to oil, frankly we see it as a distraction and a low gas price market. We continue to be very excited about that potential, and it's one of many opportunities we've got in the portfolio to accelerate gas activity when the margins and the economics are favorable in that environment. Southern Alberta Basin, I'll turn that to Gary.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Irene, I think the first part of your question was, any relationships to the overthrust. As you're probably familiar with, if you think about where Glacier National Park is in the overthrust we're a considerable distance to the east of that. So is there s
componenttext: Irene, I think the first part of your question was, any relationships to the overthrust. As you're probably familiar with, if you think about where Glacier National Park is in the overthrust we're a considerable distance to the east of that. So is there some effects? I think it's probably more likely to have some effect, its proximity to the thrust. We are seeing, just based on some ag data [ph] (1:10:10), some thermal anomalies that exist through this entire area, probably more so than what we typically think of in the Williston Basin. But it's very, very premature to think about, that we would have some understanding of that. As Lee alluded to earlier, we're going to drill eight wells this year, and that's going to allow us to better define what we think of our 227,000 acres. As far as conventional plays, early days, when we were looking at this play, we did identify some reef plays that are out there. I think it was something that was historically explored on the acreage position. Quite honestly, with the resource and the oil right now, it's on the back burner. But it's something that we could always resurrect.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Joe Magner with Macquarie Capital.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Joe Magner with Macquarie Capital.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of questions on the Granite Wash program. Can you just walk us through kind of the strategy or the latest update on your plans to test the various horizons out there between the Granite Wash, the dry gas Atoka horizon, which seems to have go
componenttext: Just a couple of questions on the Granite Wash program. Can you just walk us through kind of the strategy or the latest update on your plans to test the various horizons out there between the Granite Wash, the dry gas Atoka horizon, which seems to have gotten a lot of attention over the last couple of quarters from Newfield. And then the Marmaton, which you alluded to in the offset base [ph] (1:11:30) having a significant condensate yield, how does that compare to what you've seen out of Granite Wash.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: I'll let George Dunn take that question since he's living right in the middle of it, and he's up to the moment on what he's thinking and where he's going there.
componenttext: I'll let George Dunn take that question since he's living right in the middle of it, and he's up to the moment on what he's thinking and where he's going there.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, just as all the releases said, we'll be dominantly focusing on testing the higher condensate yield portions of the Granite Wash. I'm not sure I understood the last part of your question, but the rest of this year will be greater than 50%. And it'll
componenttext: Well, just as all the releases said, we'll be dominantly focusing on testing the higher condensate yield portions of the Granite Wash. I'm not sure I understood the last part of your question, but the rest of this year will be greater than 50%. And it'll be both testing new areas and all condensate rich stuff. The last part, I wasn't sure what you were saying, of your question.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Joe, let me see if I can grab that last bit because I think I understood. And I thought you can throw it back at us, we'll try again. The Marmaton is actually the shallowest portion of the Granite Wash sequence. Remember it's a 3,500-foot-ish plus or minu
componenttext: Joe, let me see if I can grab that last bit because I think I understood. And I thought you can throw it back at us, we'll try again. The Marmaton is actually the shallowest portion of the Granite Wash sequence. Remember it's a 3,500-foot-ish plus or minus thick section. When we've released our results, we've tested a number of zones. George's team's tested a number of zones in the Marmaton section, all of which have had good condensate yields. And we tested a number of the wells in the Atoka section, which is the deeper-most section in the Granite Wash interval, all of which were dry gas. So when we say that we're going to focus on the oily component of our Granite Wash acreage, it's telling you that we're going to drill in that upper stratigraphic section. But additional to that, we're going to continue our efforts to assess additional potential. There are over 30 individual horizons, and George will correct me if I get the number wrong, but I think we've tested four or five of those at this point all successfully. And I think his team is planning to test an additional three to four in the balance of 2010. Did I get that right, George?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we'll be, at least today til the end of the year.
componenttext: Yes, we'll be, at least today til the end of the year.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Specifically, how does the condensate yield in that shallower section compare to some of the rates that have specifically been provided out of the Granite Wash?
componenttext: Specifically, how does the condensate yield in that shallower section compare to some of the rates that have specifically been provided out of the Granite Wash?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I can tell that if you go back and you look at our release, we've got all of the rate information in the earlier Granite Wash releases. I think the first 12 or 13 wells, you can -- I don't remember the number offhand. George might, but you can get a
componenttext: Well, I can tell that if you go back and you look at our release, we've got all of the rate information in the earlier Granite Wash releases. I think the first 12 or 13 wells, you can -- I don't remember the number offhand. George might, but you can get a pretty good idea of what the actual condensate yield is. We have not released any data to go ahead and further confuse humanity with NGLs and all the conversions that get associated with that. So our reported production is field level, natural gas production and condensate. So it's pretty simple to go ahead and put our numbers together, and we do the equivalent. It's just the condensate. The condensate is 6:1 added to the gas, and we've reported all our production on MMcf equivalent basis. It is high Btu gas. The shallower sections approach 13,000 Btus, as I recall. So that's a good 30% uplift on price if you want to think about it that way. That's another attractive part of it. And I think the deeper sections in around a 1,050, 1,100 somewhere in that range Btu.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: We've had no meaningful changes. We've got a good core position in Northeast Pennsylvania. It's about 35,000 acres in that. We're working on an assessment program there. I'll just reiterate that our objective in Appalachia is to build a business. We think
componenttext: We've had no meaningful changes. We've got a good core position in Northeast Pennsylvania. It's about 35,000 acres in that. We're working on an assessment program there. I'll just reiterate that our objective in Appalachia is to build a business. We think that's a multi-year process, has been in the Mid-Con, has been in the Rockies. So we're going to go slow and take a measured approach to how we pursue additional acreage in that region.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010

componenttext: Maybe this'll be a good recap question in just kind of thinking to the rest of this year and maybe a little bit into next year, what will have to happen operationally speaking to be able to allocate something north of $700 million of CapEx to oil your projects in 2011, of course assuming that margins make sense? So what will it take maybe to take up the CapEx to $900 million or $1 billion for oil projects?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: You want to take it?
componenttext: You want to take it?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: If the time frame is in the near term, the big catalyst there would be success in the two appraisal programs that we've got out there right now. Clearly, if we have success in the Southern Alberta Basin with proximity to what we already have infrastructur
componenttext: If the time frame is in the near term, the big catalyst there would be success in the two appraisal programs that we've got out there right now. Clearly, if we have success in the Southern Alberta Basin with proximity to what we already have infrastructure, people, then we would be able to ramp that activity up pretty rapidly and deploy considerable incremental capital. The drilling campaign that we've got going right now under Bill's direction in the Maverick Basin, we go down there and drill an excess of 25 wells or so this year overall between various horizons, many of those targeting liquid-rich zones. With success there, we could also drive considerable capital investment. And I think right now, we're in a $100 million zip code there. We could go up to multiples of that. If you allow me to look out a little further, as far as capital deployment on oil projects, I mean let's not forget the discovery we made in China. That's also a big project with a lot of reserves. will generate a lot of free cash. That's something that's around the corner and with additional success we have there, we'll be able to invest more and more money that are oil directed.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: I think it's important. Gary makes a good point that back to the portfolio and diversified approach. We've got -- I think we listed them in the release on Monday evening, but we've got a train of development projects in the Gulf of Mexico, oil and compone
componenttext: I think it's important. Gary makes a good point that back to the portfolio and diversified approach. We've got -- I think we listed them in the release on Monday evening, but we've got a train of development projects in the Gulf of Mexico, oil and component training development projects in Malaysia. We're seeing the benefits, as we mentioned earlier in the call today, from investments made in prior years in each of those regions. And that's going to be an important ongoing part of our business. So we're going to hope for the success in those big areas. And could it be [ph] (1:18:25) right margins? Terry already gave you the answer. We're going to step on the accelerator wherever it makes sense.

componenttext: I would be just making numbers up to talk, but we talked about an assessment program, I'll go back and speak in Newfield speak. And If Daryll's out there and wants to correct me on a specific businesses, he can. 221,000 or 224,000 net acres in Northwestern Montana, you look at it on a map, it's a big area. So there are going to be miles between the individual wells because we're going to want to test a broad geographic area. So I'd be thinking five- to 10-mile type distances between wells would not be unreasonable. In fact, it'd be expected if you're going to go ahead and appropriately sample the subsurface.

componenttext: Well, as far as the year's out, that may not be the case. Notionally, at this point in our program, of the eight wells that we've got going out there, certainly, we've earmarked three of those to be horizontal wells and at least five of those to be pilots in which cores and extensive logging would take place. Pending the success that we have in those, it's with our full intention that those wells could be sidetracked. As far as the timing, I would think about that more as a 10/11 event.

componenttext: Yes, you bet, Gary. Dan, the permitting process is very similar to the way we handle it in our tribal acreage in the Uinta Basin with the BIA and working with the tribe to ensure that we do our on-sites. We've no issues with permitting for our program in 2010, and we'll continuing to work with the tribe, pending success on how we go forward there.

componenttext: Our next question comes from Peter Kissel with Howard Weil.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: First of all, you have a fairly strict internal mandate to spend within cash flows as you've mentioned a few times during the call. But at what point, if any, would you be willing to outspend cash flow and really accelerate even further some of these high
componenttext: First of all, you have a fairly strict internal mandate to spend within cash flows as you've mentioned a few times during the call. But at what point, if any, would you be willing to outspend cash flow and really accelerate even further some of these high rate of return oil plays that you've been talking about?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'm looking at our CFO, and he's kind of a gatekeeper to all things that look and smell like dollars. So it is an internal mandate mantra. We've stayed to this because we think it's appropriate given the business conditions of last year and this year
componenttext: Yes, I'm looking at our CFO, and he's kind of a gatekeeper to all things that look and smell like dollars. So it is an internal mandate mantra. We've stayed to this because we think it's appropriate given the business conditions of last year and this year. Clearly, we do have that ability to accelerate. I would tell you at this point, we haven't seen any of the things that we believe we would need to see in the market signaling us that stepping on the accelerator and moving faster in the plays, faster that we're moving today that makes any sense. And frankly, generating double-digit production growth, living within cash flow and high profitability oil and not overstressing the organization feels pretty good to us right now. But we're not going to sit back and take our foot off the accelerator in any plays that makes sense in terms of investing. But I think it's a good, prudent strategy through the balance of this year, and we'll just continue to reassess it as the business environment adjust.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: You talked about acquisitions and always looking there. But what about divestitures, particularly maybe for some of your high-cost international assets? And any thoughts on cleaning up the asset base at all?
componenttext: You talked about acquisitions and always looking there. But what about divestitures, particularly maybe for some of your high-cost international assets? And any thoughts on cleaning up the asset base at all?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I'm going to go ahead and jump in before our VP of International sitting at the other end of the table has a coronary. Malaysia and Southeast Asia, while there are costs associated with those operations that might be higher on a unit basis than some
componenttext: Well, I'm going to go ahead and jump in before our VP of International sitting at the other end of the table has a coronary. Malaysia and Southeast Asia, while there are costs associated with those operations that might be higher on a unit basis than some of the other areas, I would tell you that operations there are very efficient. We've got a great team. All you have to do is look back at the third quarter, fourth quarter of last year. We saw the benefits of having those assets and the production in the portfolio. Clearly, there's a lot of interest in our assets in Southeast Asia as there should be. We've got a great team delivering great results, and it's an important part of the portfolio today. Having said that, we've also been very open, that we've shown a history here over the last several years that at the right time, for the right reasons, we will divest significant portions of the business. We sold the U.K. We sold a shelf to the Gulf of Mexico. We sold a coal bed methane business in the Mid-Con all in 2007, raised $1.8 billion in those transactions, redeployed them into the Rockies and the Mid-Con and in these growth areas that we're talking about today. Frankly, you've seen the benefits today some of those decisions that were made yesterday. And we'll continue to look at the portfolio. In fact, all of our business unit leaders and their management teams are challenged with the "grow whole over divest" [ph] (1:24:10) mentality, and it's part of their day-to-day thinking. And our teams are looking at these activities. And at the right times, we'll certainly divest properties that don't have a place in the portfolio. But we have no plans, and I'll say this with emphasis, no plans and no needs to divest any portion of the portfolio today.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010

componenttext: And our final question comes from Stephen Richardson with Morgan Stanley.

componenttext: A quick question, guys, back on the Woodford. If you go to a four- to five-rig program for the balance of the year and assuming you don't slow down completions, what does that mean for your 2011 production trajectory?

componenttextpreview: Good question. I would tell you that our teams have done a great job in terms of getting the right projects, the right plays in line. We've got fantastic internal modeling done on each of our major play areas. One of the things that we track, our capital
componenttext: Good question. I would tell you that our teams have done a great job in terms of getting the right projects, the right plays in line. We've got fantastic internal modeling done on each of our major play areas. One of the things that we track, our capital maintenance level activity, I would say -- and George'll correct me if I get this a little bit wrong, but with a four-rig program, we would expect, with our gross production out of the Woodford being about 340 or 350 million cubic feet a day that we would be roughly flat in the Woodford. On a basis of year-over-year, 10 11. And that's probably close within a rig, one way or the other, of trading sideways on production there. In the Granite Wash, running four rigs. That's an asset that's going to continue to grow with a four-rig program.
