headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-23-2010
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to Newfield Exploration Second Quarter 2010 Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] And before we get started, one housekeeping matter. Our discussion with you today will contain forward-looking statements such as estimate
componenttext:
Good day, everyone, and welcome to Newfield Exploration Second Quarter 2010 Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] And before we get started, one housekeeping matter. Our discussion with you today will contain forward-looking statements such as estimated production and timing, drilling and development plans, expected cost reductions and planned capital expenditures. Although we believe the expectations reflected in these statements are reasonable, they are based on assumptions and anticipated results that are subject to numerous uncertainties and risks. Please see Newfield's annual report on Form 10-K and quarterly report on Form 10-Q for a discussion of factors that may cause actual results to vary. 
In addition, reconciliations of non-GAAP financial measures to GAAP financial measures together with Newfield's earnings release and any other applicable disclosures are available on the Investor Relations page of Newfield's website at www.newfld.com. 
At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer, Mr. Lee Boothby. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-23-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to our second quarter and midyear 2010 update call. Thanks for your interest in Newfield. With me today in Houston, I have Bill Schneider, our Vice President of Gulf Coast and International; John Jasek, Vice
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to our second quarter and midyear 2010 update call. Thanks for your interest in Newfield. With me today in Houston, I have Bill Schneider, our Vice President of Gulf Coast and International; John Jasek, Vice President of Gulf of Mexico; Steve Campbell, Vice President of Investor Relations; Terry Rathert, our Chief Financial Officer; and in Denver, we have Gary Packer, our Chief Operating Officer; and Daryll Howard, our Vice President, the Rockies; and we're joined in Tulsa by General Manager Jim Addison. 
Earlier this week, we published a detailed operations report with lots of information on our core operating regions. I will keep my remarks today relatively brief, leaving plenty of time for your questions at the end, so let's get started. 
Our focus today at Newfield is very clear. First, continue to target our investments toward oil projects. We are uniquely positioned in our peer group today with real oil projects in our portfolio. 
Our second quarter oil production was up 16% when compared to the first quarter of this year. We are on target for a 30% growth in our 2010 domestic oil volumes. The returns in oil plays today are superior to natural gas, and we're combining growth with returns. 
Second, we're assessing some major new plays that could become a significant part of our future growth. We're drilling our third well in the Southern Alberta Basin, and we currently have four rigs running in the Eagle Ford Shale assessment program down in the Maverick Basin. Combined, these oil high-yield liquid plays cover more than 500,000 net acres and hold tremendous upside potential. And third and finally, we are positioning ourselves for future performance. We continue to strive for efficiencies in our national gas developments, and we'll be in a position to again accelerate growth in gas assets when we see the appropriate return on investments. Through our diverse portfolio of assets we have multiple options to effectively manage the ups and downs in our business and navigate through the challenging elements in our business today. 
Our hedge position is strong and provides for strong cash flow and profitability over the next two years. Due to our strong capital structure, we were recently upgraded to an investment grade rating by Standard & Poor's. 
These are certainly interesting times in our business. Just days prior to our last conference call with you, the Deepwater Horizon incident occurred. The loss of life, the oil spill and its impact on the Gulf of Mexico and its shorelines are all tragedies and forceful reminders of why environment, health and safety and are critically important functions that can't be over-emphasized throughout our workforce and industry. 
Although Newfield has a long history in the Gulf of Mexico, today, it represents just 4% of our proved reserves and about 10% of our production. Our 2010 work program in the Gulf was front-end loaded, and the moratorium does not have any impact on our planned drilling programs for 2010. 
We have several active developments in the deepwater, and we fully expect we will be allowed to advance these projects. We are confident in our Gulf of Mexico team's ability to continue to execute at superlative level. Without a doubt, there will be new permitting and regulatory requirements that will impact future explorations. We are following closely all the new bills and amendments being debated in Washington, D.C., and we'll carefully weigh their impact and project economics in our future drilling plans. 
As you will hear in today's call, we have a deep portfolio and plenty of options. We're confident that the options we possess and our ability to shift capital and human resources between business units will enable us to navigate the uncertain times ahead and continue to deliver profitable growth. 
By now, I hope you've had a chance to review our second quarter financial results. Our pre-FAS 133 numbers were $1.06 per share. Our production volumes were at the upper end of guidance, and our costs and expenses were within our guidance ranges. Terry Rathert, our CFO, will be happy to take any questions you may have regarding our quarterly results at the end of this call. 
For 2010, our capital budget remains at $1.6 billion, unchanged. For the remainder of the call, I will use our time to update you on recent developments in our most significant plays starting with our growing oil developments. 
For some time now, we've had a view that oil would be advantaged over natural gas. We backed this belief by hedging a substantial portion of our future natural gas production. In fact, we hedged a greater percentage over a longer time period than has typically been the norm. I would encourage you to take a look at our hedge disclosure in our NFX publications. The prolonged weakness in natural gas prices is being further exacerbated by a continually rising rig count. Apparently, the need to hold acreage by production supersedes economics, and gas supply remains stubbornly high today. 
We are hedged with strong gas prices for 2010 and 2011, but because we have options, we are focusing on our oil projects today to deliver impressive growth. Recently, there've been lots of questions on NGLs and the recent price erosion. This is a very minor issue for Newfield as most of our liquid production is oil. 
In the second quarter, natural gas liquids, NGLs, represented 2.5 BCF or about 3% of our total production. This is up from about 1 1/2 BCF when compared to the second quarter of 2009, primarily reflecting our growth in the Granite Wash play. So in short, weaker NGL pricing is not a material issue for Newfield since our growth stems largely from real oil, not NGLs. 
Our domestic oil growth today is coming from the Rocky Mountains through our Monument Butte and Williston assets, and I'll talk a little bit about those at this time starting with Monument Butte. This is our most significant growth asset today. It's a giant oil resource play capable of many years of double-digit production increases. We recently set a production record at Monument Butte of about 22,600 barrels per day. That's up 5,600 barrels of oil per day since year end 2009. We're well on our way to reaching our year end 2010 target of at least 25,000 barrels of oil per day. This field is the largest contributor to our estimated 30% growth in domestic oil production in 2010. 
Our 2010 joint team in Monument Butte continues to impress and set a recent drilling record of 2.8 days. That's rig up to rig release, and it was on a 20-acre directional well. Our improved drilling efficiencies are allowing us to drill an estimated 375 wells this year with a five-rig program. It really puts it in perspective when you realize that we are turning a new oil well to sales everyday now. This is the essence of a resource play, and we are fortunate to have one that's oil. 
About 95% of our expected 2010 Monument Butte production is sold under term sales, and 85% of our 2011 forward production has termed. Current differentials remain at about $13 to $14 below NYMEX, including about $6 per barrel of transportation expense. We're working with area refiners to ensure their capacity keeps pace with our future supply growth. 
Our results on our northern extension acreage are strong, and three of our five operated rigs continue drilling on a 63,000 net acre area. We've drilled 90 wells in this acreage in 2010 and 220 wells since 2007 when we started drilling in that region. 
To give you an idea of the success we're having, a recent well here posted initial average production of 350 barrels per day over its first 30 days of production. In total, we estimate that there are currently about 4,700 development drilling locations remaining in the Monument Butte area. 
I'll move on now to the Williston Basin. Our production in this region is ahead of original plans and has nearly doubled since the beginning of the year. Net production today is more than 4,000 barrels of oil equivalent. We added a fourth operated rig to our program last week and expect that our net production at year end 2010 will be about 6,500 barrels per day in this region. We have about 160,000 net acres under active development along the Nesson and the west of the Nesson, and year-to-date, we expect to drill 25-or-so wells in the full year 2010 cycle. 
Most of our producing wells today have had lateral lengths of around 4,000 feet. We expect in the second half that half of these wells we'll drill will have extended lateral lengths up to as long as 9,000 feet. We continue to evolve our completion designs to achieve the best results. 
In our operations release, we detailed recent well results, and you can see several of the wells with initial production rates in excess of 3,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day and 30-day averages of 1,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day or more. In our Westberg development area on the Nesson Anticline, our recent Garvey Federal 1-29 well is our best to-date and had an initial production rate of more than 3,800 barrels of oil equivalent per day from a 3,900-foot lateral. 
We're also seeing good results in our new assessment areas west of the Nesson. In the Aquarium/Watford area, our Bluefin well had an IP of about 2,500 barrels of oil equivalent per day and was our first Bakken well on this acreage area. 
More than half our remaining 20-or-so wells this year will have lateral lengths of approximately 9,000 feet. As a result of our improved drilling and completions, we're now seeing increased EURs in a range of 500,000 to 750,000 barrels. 
Recent drilling complete costs for the Williston wells range from $6 million to $8 million gross. 
I'll move on now to Malaysia. Our international oil production was up nearly 10% in the second quarter of 2010 compared to the same period in 2009. The primary driver was Malaysia. Our East Belumut field on PM 323 has performed ahead of expectations in the first half of the year. 
In the second quarter, our net production from Malaysia averaged about 15,000 barrels of oil per day. Unfortunately, as we reported last week, our export pipeline was damaged by an unidentified marine vessel working nearly 20 miles from our East Belumut field. Repairs to the damaged pipeline are expected to take six to eight weeks, and last week, we estimated that the deferred production related to the downtime will total about 500,000 net barrels. Repairs are now underway, and we will update you again when production resumes. We have several new developments underway in Malaysia that are expected to provide additional growth in 2011 and 2012. 
I'll move on now to talk a little bit about building for the future. While our oil production is at record levels, we continue to build for the future and are assessing some significant new oil resource plays, some of which you are aware of, some that you are not. Maverick Basin will be where I'll start. Without a doubt, the Eagle Ford Shale is one of the hottest plays underway today in the U.S. Rig counts continue to rise, and access to completion services remain tight. We have more than 300,000 net acres in the highly prospective Eagle Ford and Pearsall Shale plays and are investing about $100 million this year to thoroughly assess our acreage. 
As of this morning, we are now running five operated rigs in the Maverick Basin and expect to drill about 15 wells in the second half of this year. Nine of these wells will be targeted to Eagle Ford Shale, and the remaining wells will be drilled to the deeper Pearsall Shale. We've drilled two wells to-date, about to TD a third. The first well was a 5,000-foot lateral in the lower Eagle Ford oil window in the northern portion of our acreage. The second was also a 5,000-foot lateral in the wet gas window in the southern portion of our acreage. 
We have a frac crew scheduled to arrive next week, and we'll have our first flow rates very soon. Our completions will be arranged back to back, and we will utilize a completion crew that will work exclusively for Newfield. This ensures that we get the best possible quality and control the timing of our jobs. 
It's important to understand that this is a true assessment program. Simply stated, this means we are sampling our acreage from north to south and intend to be in a position to understand its potential later this year or early next. We will not be making individual well results public and plan to update you of the package of well results at an appropriate time later this year or early next year. 
I'll move on now to the Southern Alberta Basin. We have a similar assessment program underway on our 230,000 net acres in the Southern Alberta Basin of Northern Montana. Prospective formations here are the Lodgepole, Middle Bakken, Sanish and the deeper Nisku. We are preparing to spud our third well now and plan to drill as many as eight wells before year end. We will test both vertical and horizontal wells in multiple formations. Again, we will not be discussing individual well results and plan to update you on the package of wells when we have a comprehensive understanding of our acreage and its potential. 
Although we're not in a position to identify them yet, we're applying our geological lessons learned to new oil plays. These are homegrown plays and have significant potential. Our geoscientists have done a great job of identifying these plays and positioning us early as opposed to being a follower and playing at premium entry price. Acreage costs really do impact economics. I look forward to sharing results with you in the future as we gain additional information. 
I'll move on and talk a little bit about our held-by-production gas plays, plays that are capable of providing growth at the right time. In our operations release, we provided updates on our Mid-Continent resource plays, the Granite Wash and the Woodford Shale. 
Our Mid-Continent division set a recent production record of 360 million cubic feet per day, net. We've been able to grow production over the last several quarters despite a falling rig count in the region 
In the second quarter, we set a Woodford production record of more than 370 million cubic feet a day gross, and we expect that with the decreased rig count, the Woodford production will still grow more than 20% this year. The reallocation of capital, our gas directed rig count, has been slowed to facilitate acceleration in our oil plays. When stronger national gas prices improve economics, we will be in a position to quickly grow our held-by-production gas assets with proven and predictable results. 
Our rig count at the Woodford has decreased from nine rigs at the beginning of the year to four rigs operating today, so we continue to post efficiency gains. An example of this would be our lateral penetration rates, which have improved more than 20% year-to-date versus our average historical numbers. This significant gain in penetration rate allows us to do more with fewer rigs. We're drilling the longer laterals, and we're drilling them faster. 
Our assessment of multiple prospective horizons in the Granite Wash play continues, and by year end, we expect to have tested at least 10 different horizons. We are electing to conduct this comprehensive assessment this year to fully understand the stock potential on our acreage. It's important to remember that we are not simply drilling in one sweet spot. 
To-date, we have drilled 26 horizontal wells across our 46,000 net acre position. We recently drilled our longest lateral to-date in the Granite Wash with nearly 6,300 feet. About half of our planned wells in the second half of 2010 will be drilled to the Marmaton formation where we've seen high liquid yields, helping to improve economics. 
The Granite Wash is our highest return gas play, and we currently plan to run four operator rigs through the balance of 2010. Our current net reduction in the region is around 80 million cubic feet per day. 
Before I conclude our prepared remarks and move to take your questions, let me offer a few insights on what we believe makes Newfield a preferred investment today. Number one, we have options. We have attractive oil and gas assets, and we're pulling the right levers to combine growth and returns. We're confident that our diverse portfolio provides an advantage as we navigate effectively through the challenges in our business environment today. 
Number two, we're making investment decisions around returns. We realize that growth is important, but it's imperative that drilling decisions are based on economics. Our hedge position is very strong, but we are not using our natural gas hedge position as rationale for gas drilling. We are slowing our gas developments because we can and channeling our dollars to oil to capitalize on returns. We will be on a very short list of companies that can grow domestic production in excess of 20% or more in 2010. 
Number three, we are building for our future. Although our budget in 2010 is driven by our expectations for cash flow and our commitment to live within cash flow, keep in mind that there is more than $150 million allocated to assessing new oil and gas plays. It would be easy to simply allocate these dollars for our current development plays, but we must continue to build for the future. Our new assessments have the potential to rise to the top of our investment pyramid and if successful could be a significant part of our future growth in production and reserves. 
Thanks for your continued support of Newfield Exploration. That concludes our prepared remarks this morning. We're happy to take your questions at this time.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-23-2010
componenttextpreview: I would say that our activity is relative to deferred completions from 2009. Most of that activity played out late first quarter, early second quarter. I would say that accessing those completions is now behind us. The record production that we recorded i
componenttext: I would say that our activity is relative to deferred completions from 2009. Most of that activity played out late first quarter, early second quarter. I would say that accessing those completions is now behind us. The record production that we recorded in May out of the Woodford Shale, the gross production I referenced of 370 million a day was related to the ongoing drilling efforts as well as that surge from those deferred completions. We do have the option, as the second half unfolds, to defer some completions into 2011, and since we've done that before, we'll monitor the market conditions as things play out, and certainly, that's one of the tools in our toolkit, and we'll use it if we think it's appropriate, but at this time, all of the deferred completions from 2009 are behind us.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-23-2010
componenttextpreview: And would you give some -- your comments about oil versus gas are well noted. Would you have any interest or ability to further shift your capital spending towards oil and less gas, and sort of along those lines, it sounds like the four rigs you're runnin
componenttext: And would you give some -- your comments about oil versus gas are well noted. Would you have any interest or ability to further shift your capital spending towards oil and less gas, and sort of along those lines, it sounds like the four rigs you're running in the Woodford, are those two hold acreage and so you can't slow down beyond the four rigs?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-23-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I'll remind you that in the Woodford -- let me start there, and I'll work my way backwards to your question. In the Woodford, we're substantially held by production. Up until this quarter, we've reported a net acreage number of around 166,000 net ac
componenttext: Well, I'll remind you that in the Woodford -- let me start there, and I'll work my way backwards to your question. In the Woodford, we're substantially held by production. Up until this quarter, we've reported a net acreage number of around 166,000 net acres. You'll note in our release it's up over 172,000 net acres as we have added to our position in the Woodford, but of that, 155-ish, somewhere in that zip code of those acres are held by production. So we have very little requirements for HBP drilling in the Woodford. The same story is true in the Granite Wash. We have four rigs running in the Granite Wash as well, and I was careful to point out that our current plans relate to continuing to have those rigs running now through the end of the year, but as with the completions, we'll continue to monitor this situation, and we do have options in the portfolio. We've been shifting towards oil all year, and it's something we'll continue to consider on an ongoing basis in the second half of this year. The biggest variables there really are assessment programs in the Maverick Basin and the Southern Alberta Basin, but we really think those will be mostly a 2011-'12-type event.

componenttext: No, we've seen a very good appetite for the Black Wax that we've produced from Monument Butte. That is not a contracted volume. headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-23-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, as far as the EURs that we have there, that range captures not only the 6 40s or the 4,000-foot laterals through the 12 80s, but it also is meant to capture the on-Nesson Anticline and off-Nesson Anticline volumes. To-date, our historical type curve
componenttext: Yes, as far as the EURs that we have there, that range captures not only the 6 40s or the 4,000-foot laterals through the 12 80s, but it also is meant to capture the on-Nesson Anticline and off-Nesson Anticline volumes. To-date, our historical type curve that we've been using for the short laterals has evolved into about 450 to 500 MBO. As in the update, we plan to drill a majority of our wells throughout the remainder of this year on 12 80s or 9,000 to 10,000 foot, and we think that 5 to 7 50 captures the range of the EURs we'll see there, and while we haven't actually drilled wells like that today, we have an abundance of information on and immediately adjacent to our acreage position and feel real comfortable with it.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-23-2010
componenttextpreview: And as you move to drilling more than I guess half of your wells for the rest of 2010 as long laterals in the Bakken, are there any areas that you're limited to where you have drill the short laterals? Is there any regional differences where you would cho
componenttext: And as you move to drilling more than I guess half of your wells for the rest of 2010 as long laterals in the Bakken, are there any areas that you're limited to where you have drill the short laterals? Is there any regional differences where you would choose to drill the short, and I'm thinking kind of the Nesson versus the Big Valley area?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-23-2010
componenttextpreview: The only area that we would preferentially drill the shorter laterals, historically, has been up on the Nesson Anticline, and it's been more driven by the acreage blocks that we currently hold and the offset operators. As we would drill longer laterals, w
componenttext: The only area that we would preferentially drill the shorter laterals, historically, has been up on the Nesson Anticline, and it's been more driven by the acreage blocks that we currently hold and the offset operators. As we would drill longer laterals, we would need to put larger spacing units together, which typically get into operatorship issues. As we move off the Nesson and move in to areas such as Catwalk, Watford, Aquarium and the like, we have larger contiguous positions, and we're more free to drill the longer laterals, so there wouldn't be a geologic reason.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-23-2010
componenttextpreview: And as I look at the 30-day rates on the short laterals, they just seem pretty strong to, I guess, what my expectations were at least. What are you guys doing from the completions side? I understand that it's 10 to 12 frac stages, but in terms of ceramic,
componenttext: And as I look at the 30-day rates on the short laterals, they just seem pretty strong to, I guess, what my expectations were at least. What are you guys doing from the completions side? I understand that it's 10 to 12 frac stages, but in terms of ceramic, how much ceramic are you putting away and just kind of any general thoughts on the well quality so far.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-23-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, as far as the stages go, we're probably pushing 14 to 16 stages versus the 11 and 12, so we've certainly evolved in that regard. I would say that we're probably opening these wells up in a little bit more controlled manner than maybe some of the num
componenttext: Well, as far as the stages go, we're probably pushing 14 to 16 stages versus the 11 and 12, so we've certainly evolved in that regard. I would say that we're probably opening these wells up in a little bit more controlled manner than maybe some of the numbers you're used to see, and then therefore, you have maybe a little lower decline than what you may have anticipated. We're tailing with ceramics, so we're pumping sand for a bulk of the job then tailing with ceramics, so that's kind of how we're evolving that. Other than that, I just think we're in some good areas, and therefore, if you look you're comparing our results versus an average across the basin, you may just be seeing that rocks makes a difference.

componenttext: Typically, we're anticipating four rigs, and that's kind of where we're currently bringing the fleet down to, so we ought to be able to essentially be in equilibrium as we look forward at that level. headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-23-2010
componenttextpreview: And separately, taking a step back on capital spending, can you just refresh us on what you are thinking about this year and next year in terms of capital spending, and when you think about your hedging gains and spending within cash flow,I mean, you ob
componenttext:
And separately, taking a step back on capital spending, can you just refresh us on what you are thinking about this year and next year in terms of capital spending, and when you think about your hedging gains and spending within cash flow,
I mean, you obviously have significant hedging gains this year and it look's like depending on the price deck on track to have hedging gains next year. When you think about your CapEx, do you think about spending within cash flow before hedging gains, or using hedging gains as an opportunity to do some of the exploration work that you were talking about earlier?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-23-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, you know, Brian, we've been consistent, obviously, we've been a hedger for a long time and we've always hedged for the same reasons to underpin our operating programs, and we're not planning our business on the fluctuations day-to-day or week-to-wee
componenttext: Well, you know, Brian, we've been consistent, obviously, we've been a hedger for a long time and we've always hedged for the same reasons to underpin our operating programs, and we're not planning our business on the fluctuations day-to-day or week-to-week and we need a longer-term view. And given the nature of the large-scale operations, it's not an efficient thing to do to speed up, slowdown, put your foot on the brake one day and the accelerator the next. So it really gives us the operating flexibility to look a little bit further into the future and plan and allow our operating teams to continue to execute. As far as the commitments on capital programs, we have said out on the road that it's our intent to maintain our commitment to live within cash flow until such point in time that we consider the economic conditions such that it makes sense to do something else. I don't know when that time is going to be. We doubt it's going to be this year. Our hedged position tells you that we doubt it's going to be next year. But clearly, it's our policy not to comment on budgets next year because we're halfway through 2010. We're focused on '10. But I would say the assumptions, and until we tell you otherwise, that we're committed to live within cash flow, that's going to remain in place. And that excludes the acquisitions, obviously, we're looking kind of a rolling two-year average in that regard. Maverick Basin, TXCO acquisition would be one of those items. We've got nothing else on the horizon on that area, and we've got plenty of work to do between now and the end of the year that sets our new programs.

But as you continue to enjoy success, we have to look at all options, and there probably are some out there. But right now, we're feeling pretty comfortable where we're at.

componenttextpreview: Let's go to Uinta Basin, Monument Butte. I noticed back, a few months back, you guys permitted some wells and some horizontal wells out of Monument Butte. Any update on those particular wells? Have you drilled those? Any future potential regarding [ph] ho
componenttext: Let's go to Uinta Basin, Monument Butte. I noticed back, a few months back, you guys permitted some wells and some horizontal wells out of Monument Butte. Any update on those particular wells? Have you drilled those? Any future potential regarding [ph] horizontal in the basin?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-23-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we've been looking at horizontal well plans at Monument Butte for years. And as we built the competency, internal with the company, we've expanded that here into the Rockies. We've permitted a number of wells I believe, horizontally, targeting variou
componenttext: Yes, we've been looking at horizontal well plans at Monument Butte for years. And as we built the competency, internal with the company, we've expanded that here into the Rockies. We've permitted a number of wells I believe, horizontally, targeting various horizons. We've drilled one to date and it's not completed at this time. As you know, David, I mean, the sands are very variable in the field, so you have to be very careful in how you target these. But with the amount of work that's been done geologically, we feel like we've identified areas in the field where there's sufficient continuity to drill a horizontal. And in those areas, we've mapped it out. And I think it's just one of those things as we continue to apply more and more technology to the play, we have the opportunity here to see some good results. So we're excited about it, but we just don't have any results at this time.

componenttext: Yes. It has no relationship with us. We have what I would describe as, an outstanding relationship with the Ute Tribe, as good as we have with any partner throughout the organization, and we look to continue to build on that relationship. And from what I'm aware of, and I have nothing more than what you've read, that appear to be more of a one-off situation between Questar and themselves.

componenttext: And then just more on a macro-gas level, you guys mentioned the ability to ramp up gas production when it makes economic sense. What are you guys looking at to make that decision? Is it the one-year strip, two-year strip? How do you guys think about that?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-23-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I guess, being the keeper of the margin calculations, I would say that, when we think that we have margins with that activity to compete with other investment opportunities we around the company, then we'll go back to, really, putting it to drilling
componenttext: Well, I guess, being the keeper of the margin calculations, I would say that, when we think that we have margins with that activity to compete with other investment opportunities we around the company, then we'll go back to, really, putting it to drilling in those areas. It's always going to be about margins. And it's not price, it's margin. And we have to look at the cost that underlie that, an operating costs and the value of products. So we'll keep in tune with what the margins in each of these areas are as we go forward and make the decisions, and capital allocation based upon returns.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-23-2010

componenttext: We'll hear next from Joe Allman of JPMorgan.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-23-2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of the Granite Wash, have any of the 26 wells that you've drilled been a second well under the same acreage? And do you plan on doing that if whether or not you've done that?
componenttext: In terms of the Granite Wash, have any of the 26 wells that you've drilled been a second well under the same acreage? And do you plan on doing that if whether or not you've done that?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-23-2010
componenttextpreview: Joe, if you go back to our original release, and I'm trying to remember, I think, it was July of last year, I think, there were a half a dozen wells, somewhere there about six, seven wells, and read the names of the wells very carefully, there were three
componenttext: Joe, if you go back to our original release, and I'm trying to remember, I think, it was July of last year, I think, there were a half a dozen wells, somewhere there about six, seven wells, and read the names of the wells very carefully, there were three wells with the name McCoy on it. They were all drilled into the same horizon in the Marmaton, one on the east side of the section, one on the west of the section, and I guess you can guess where the third one was, right in the middle. We did that as an initial test early in the program to go ahead and ascertain two things. Number one, variability and deliverability relative to petrophysics within individual target horizons. The east and west sides of that block, we had better petrophysics from the vertical drilling program. In the center, we saw a somewhat deteriorated section. What we found is where we had good rock on the east and west. They performed much better than the rock in the central portion of the section. But all three wells were very good wells, and they've continued to perform very well. So that's, to my knowledge, the only three wells, single-zone section. So you could say a couple hundred acres per well-type volume allocation, relative to the section that we've done. But we did it early, and we've got that in our back pocket in terms of performance as we plan the future development. Our focus has been on assessing the individual horizons. We've talked about there being as many as 30 individual horizons. And I think we're about seven horizon had been now through our testing. So if you think about 26 wells and take the three that I just told you they were in the same zone out, you can get it in appreciation that we've got a relatively sparse drilling within the individual target horizons. And the point there is, we want to understand what the inventory looks like on our acreage, so that we can get it planned appropriately within our portfolio model and future plans. We'll have about 10 of those horizons tested by year end, which is right in line with our pre-2010 expectations.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-23-2010

componenttext: And then on a different topic, and you referred to this a little bit, but just go across your different key operating areas and just talk about what you're seeing with service costs, and where are you really seeing a lot of pressure?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-23-2010
componenttextpreview: I would say, a bulk of the cost inflation we've seen is certainly on the pumping services. Oil country tubular goods has been up as much as 20% throughout the organization. Rig rates, as you're probably aware, depending on where you want to start from the
componenttext: I would say, a bulk of the cost inflation we've seen is certainly on the pumping services. Oil country tubular goods has been up as much as 20% throughout the organization. Rig rates, as you're probably aware, depending on where you want to start from the ultimate low, could have seen somewhere between 30% to 50%. However, we've had much of that has been either baked into our numbers as we entered the year or under rig contracts. So we haven't seen that translate into the well cost as much. But just as an industry number, that's probably pretty appropriate. On the pumping services side, that number could probably be in its regionally variable in areas like the Bakken and the Eagle Ford, as has already been addressed, as extremely competitive. So you could have seen certainly 30%, 35% annual increases in pumping services there. In some cases, maybe you hear more. In other areas, like the Monument Butte, the number would be less than that. So on a completion basis, you can probably take about half of those figures and say, that's what our completion costs are up. So that, on average, I'd say about 15%. On the drilling side, we've seen cost increases anywhere between 5% and 20%, depending on where you're at.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-23-2010
componenttextpreview: Canaccord's Irene Haas has our next question.
componenttext: Canaccord's Irene Haas has our next question.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-23-2010
componenttextpreview: Just want to get a feel as to how you guys think about the gas market because you mentioned earlier, rig counts are still high. Nobody's blinking. How do you see those whole thing played out? And what do you think needs to happen to tighten supply? And al
componenttext: Just want to get a feel as to how you guys think about the gas market because you mentioned earlier, rig counts are still high. Nobody's blinking. How do you see those whole thing played out? And what do you think needs to happen to tighten supply? And along the same thought process, are you guys had [ph] a little cooling down on the Marcellus trends since even with you're more established transitions to Woodford, you're pulling back rig count. How do you feel about the Marcellus at this point?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-23-2010
componenttextpreview: Let's see, you've jammed a number of things and I'll try to get them all and if I happen to miss it, Irene you can go ahead and remind me and I'll come back to it. So let's start with the Marcellus. Our plan in the Marcellus, we've been very clear. We've
componenttext: Let's see, you've jammed a number of things and I'll try to get them all and if I happen to miss it, Irene you can go ahead and remind me and I'll come back to it. So let's start with the Marcellus. Our plan in the Marcellus, we've been very clear. We've built a team, its a quality team. We see the Marcellus as a substantially significant long-term source of supply in North America. We believe we need to be represented there, but we're going to be very judicious and diligent in terms of our efforts, and we expect it to be a multiyear effort to build the business in Appalachia. So we haven't changed our position relative to our thoughts on the Marcellus and the team continues to evaluate opportunity each and everyday. Relative to natural gas and the decrease in the rig count in the Woodford, clearly, I had to go back to Terry's comments on margin. I mean, we've got oil in the portfolio and we've options to accelerate, and we've been exercising those options for most of the last year now, and your seeing the results come through in terms of growing domestic oil volumes. I think that's significant. It's driven by attractive margins. So we're going to do everything we can to make sure that we get the best investments at the front of the line and that we keep them there. So we monitor that on a realtime basis and we'll shift accordingly, and I think we've learned a lot over the last year and half or so in terms of our ability to shift, not just capital, but human resources around within the organization. And I think it's a real competitive advantage in the type of market that we're in today. As far as the natural gas market, which I think was your other question in the leadoff, we've been bearish, as you'll recall, since exiting 2008, '09, '10 and '11, and I think that we've not been surprised by how things have played out. I think as long as the rig count continues to run up, and we're being driven by HBP efforts and natural gas plays, it's almost inevitable that you'll continue to be oversupplied. And obviously, in a commodity market, that's bearish and would tend to lead to low-price outcomes in that regard. Having said that, I think once the HBP flurry is behind the industry, and we can get some folks through the flood of money coming in internationally, promoted dollars, then maybe we can get back to more a normal situation where the balanced industry is making economic decisions and making investments on the merits as opposed to making investments for other reasons, which I think is a lot of what's driving the buoyant rig count that we see today. So it's not going to turn over until the rig count turns over and if we get back to a more appropriate supply-demand situation.

componenttext: Well, we certainly hope so. I'll leave it at that. I mean, I don't have the magic wand to go ahead and tell you which date, which month, which year, which quarter that's going to occur. But I sleep pretty good at night thinking about 2010 and '11. That's our focus right now.

componenttext: Well, we have actually kind of cut back on our flowback program a little bit to be able to kind of manage those near-term rates a little bit. I think in general, our first year, our first choke size is in the 30s, low-30s, from that standpoint. We have seen some bit of a reduced decline in that first year, and you're seeing that when we reported our IP rates and our 30-day averages. So we think it's real early. We're collecting that data. But we do believe that we're seeing some expanded or decreased first-year rates.

componenttext: Pressure rates have declined.

componenttext: Decline, yes. When it goes on pump, it's pretty well specific and it's pretty area specific. It really depends on kind of the flowback floor we're at. That can be anywhere from three months to six months.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-23-2010
componenttextpreview: And then turning to the Uinta Basin, you can say the squeeze-out days on the drill time with the, I guess, the year-to-date average now being 4.5 days. So what does that mean in terms of cost savings? Can you give us a reference on that? And, I guess, may
componenttext: And then turning to the Uinta Basin, you can say the squeeze-out days on the drill time with the, I guess, the year-to-date average now being 4.5 days. So what does that mean in terms of cost savings? Can you give us a reference on that? And, I guess, maybe, why the somewhat wide range in the cost estimate of 700k to 900k per location? And then lastly, can you speak about spacing in the play?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-23-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. Let's see. As we move to more reduced days, it actually, ultimately requires increased cost in our overall capital budget because we're drilling more wells. As a result of the efficiency gains this year, off the top of my head, when we went from 5.5
componenttext: Okay. Let's see. As we move to more reduced days, it actually, ultimately requires increased cost in our overall capital budget because we're drilling more wells. As a result of the efficiency gains this year, off the top of my head, when we went from 5.5 days down to 4.5 days, we're going to consume about an extra $80 million this year and CapEx as a result of that. Now the reason we have such a wide range in capital cost is the play actually gets deeper as you move south to north and then not only that, our in-fill wells are all directionally drilled. And more specifically, remember in those costs also, we have our infrastructure costs or tank batteries. So there's a wide variety of factors that could affect a specific well outcome, size of the battery, depth, directional versus straight hull. As far as the spacing goes, on the tribal side, we're drilling many of these wells are on 40s or even, as we step out, these wells could be the first well in a 640, okay? So the infrastructure cost could be higher as a result of that. As we step back into Monument Butte, that is primarily a combination of 40-acre vertical wells as we continue to extend the play. But in addition to that, we're also drilling directional wells from existing pads, which are 20 acres, and that makes up the balance of the Monument Butte proper play.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-23-2010
componenttextpreview: What is your lowest ranking asset maybe in terms of economic breakeven or return on investment? And maybe, what's the future for that asset?
componenttext: What is your lowest ranking asset maybe in terms of economic breakeven or return on investment? And maybe, what's the future for that asset?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-23-2010
componenttextpreview: We don't have a lowest ranking asset that I'm going to disclose. I mean, I would say that if you look at our behaviors, the lowest ranking asset, in terms of capital investment, was our deep high-pressure high-temperature drilling program in the conventio
componenttext: We don't have a lowest ranking asset that I'm going to disclose. I mean, I would say that if you look at our behaviors, the lowest ranking asset, in terms of capital investment, was our deep high-pressure high-temperature drilling program in the conventional deep target along the Texas Gulf Coast and we abandoned that effort over a year ago. And today, our Gulf Coast onshore is managing the production associated with those producing assets, which generate really attractive cash flow that's going into our resource plays today. But all of our drilling investments are directed towards assessment programs relative to the Maverick Basin. So we've reshaped that team, and that's kind of a normal cycle. I think the IQ test is, not what you've done historically if that production provides cash flow, it's the incremental investments that you make on a perspective basis. Do they make economic sense? Do they have attractive margins? Do they degenerate the required returns so that you can be a healthy self-sustaining business? And I think that's a question, frankly that more people should ask themselves.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-23-2010
componenttextpreview: Bob, I think one of the key questions there in terms of to complete or not complete is really a timing decision. And if we were to hit really low gas prices and had better use for the capital on an immediate basis, we'd move it somewhere else. As a practi
componenttext: Bob, I think one of the key questions there in terms of to complete or not complete is really a timing decision. And if we were to hit really low gas prices and had better use for the capital on an immediate basis, we'd move it somewhere else. As a practical matter, that's a timing decision, not an investment decision per se. So we continue to have pretty good gas prices. We're still getting good returns on our drilling there. I can tell you, the returns aren't as high as drilling Monument Butte, 20- and 40-acre oil wells. So it's really more a function of looking at the total return and timing.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-23-2010
componenttextpreview: And in that regard, you mentioned that the Granite Wash was your highest return in gas pipes. Just ignoring capital allocation issues and what other alternatives you might have, what gas price does that give you an acceptable rate of return, is it $3? And
componenttext: And in that regard, you mentioned that the Granite Wash was your highest return in gas pipes. Just ignoring capital allocation issues and what other alternatives you might have, what gas price does that give you an acceptable rate of return, is it $3? And I know you're testing a lot of horizons, but have you mentioned them as your highest return gas play, again, ignoring the capital allocation issues, is that something that's economic in your mind at $4, $3, $2, what is the level of there?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-23-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, maybe the best way to think about that is look at the large quantity of proven and probable reserves they put on the books at year end 2009 in a sub-$4 gas price environment. So some of those were carrying in cost that we have had rigs unde
componenttext: Well, I think, maybe the best way to think about that is look at the large quantity of proven and probable reserves they put on the books at year end 2009 in a sub-$4 gas price environment. So some of those were carrying in cost that we have had rigs under contract for some period of time. So clearly, all those are very -- they're working at sub-$4. Go back to when my earlier comments, if we remain in the sub-$4 gas price environment and we don't have competitive and other pressures pushing service costs and cost corrected to a $4 environment, so like rolling back to 2003, right? And we have that kind of cost environment, these things are tremendously exciting in terms of returns. $4 with gas price with the day rates that you have to pay if you were drilling in the Haynesville, it doesn't get very exciting. So if the rig is back to that margin question and when you have a dislocation in the service cost side because of abnormal forces driving pumping service, cost or drilling rig rate cost, things of that nature, kind of distorts the return and you get this little dislocation for a period of time. In a normal environment, $4, those things would be very attractive.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-23-2010
componenttextpreview: And when you mentioned the margin environment, you talked about the increases in costs, both completion and drilling. At a constant gas price, it doesn't matter what you pay, if you pay $4 or $5, heavy drilling efficiency to longer laterals, to shorter dr
componenttext: And when you mentioned the margin environment, you talked about the increases in costs, both completion and drilling. At a constant gas price, it doesn't matter what you pay, if you pay $4 or $5, heavy drilling efficiency to longer laterals, to shorter drilling times, overall offset those cost increases over the past year so at a fixed-price margins have held steady? Or they more than offsetting those cost inflation pressures so that your margins are actually improving over the past year at a cost to gas price?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-23-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, clearly, we have seen a significant increases or improvements in terms of drilling efficiency, and what that has done is drive the cost per completed lateral footdown. I think there is some charts in our -- different historical materials on our webs
componenttext: Well, clearly, we have seen a significant increases or improvements in terms of drilling efficiency, and what that has done is drive the cost per completed lateral footdown. I think there is some charts in our -- different historical materials on our website that show how dramatically we have decreased those costs per foot of well completed. So if you're just thinking of constant gas price, it translates directly into a huge pickup in terms of rate of return. And that was in light of, right, a service-cost environment that was relatively static at the time. If you put an over pin on that, and it's okay. So you could stand that kind of an increase in cost and have a fixed return. You can't go through the mental gymnastics of what you could tolerate in the context of what's happening in the service cost as we have continued improvement in efficiency.

componenttext: I would say that, all things being equal, it's probably been more or less flat. Maybe down a little bit, but we've had some great improvements and efficiency.
