headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to Newfield Exploration Third Quarter 2010 Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] And before we get started, one housekeeping matter.Our discussion with you today will contain forward-looking statements such as estimate
componenttext:
Good day, everyone, and welcome to Newfield Exploration Third Quarter 2010 Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] And before we get started, one housekeeping matter.
Our discussion with you today will contain forward-looking statements such as estimated production and timing, drilling and development plans, expected cost reductions and planned capital expenditures. Although we believe that the expectations reflected in these statements are reasonable, they are based upon assumptions and anticipated results that are subject to numerous uncertainties and risks. Please see Newfield's annual report on Form 10-K and quarterly reports on Form 10-Q for a discussion of factors that may cause actual results to vary.
In addition, reconciliations of non-GAAP financial measures to GAAP financial measures together with Newfield's earnings release and any other applicable disclosures are available on the Investor Relations page of Newfield's website at www.newfield.com.
At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to the Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer, Mr. Lee Boothby. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, everyone. I appreciate you hanging with us through what appeared to be some technical difficulties.  And those of who had to call back in, I appreciate you calling back in. So I apologize for the delay, but we'll get moving with t
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, everyone. I appreciate you hanging with us through what appeared to be some technical difficulties.  And those of who had to call back in, I appreciate you calling back in. So I apologize for the delay, but we'll get moving with the call.
Welcome to the third quarter conference call. I'd like to thank all of you for your continued interest in Newfield. Very quickly, by way of introduction, I'll announce that Gary Packer, our Chief Operating Officer; Terry Rathert, our Chief Financial Officer; Brian Rickmers, our Controller; Steve Campbell, VP of Investor Relations; and John Jasek, VP of Gulf of Mexico are with me here in Houston. And remotely, we have George Dunn, who runs our Mid-Continent business on the line as well.
Along with our earnings release, we issued a separate operations release yesterday updating you on our core focus areas. If we don't address your questions on our prepared remarks this morning, we'll have plenty of time at the end of the call.
If you've seen us recently on the road, you know that our focus is clear. We are delivering on our promises and have our sights fixed on meeting our 2010 year end objectives. From our guidance, you'll see that our production growth will not be less than 11% year-over-year, the upper end of our original guidance range entering 2010.
We are investing in our oil projects and slowing our activities in natural gas plays. Our most recent tally shows that more than 50% of this year's $1.6 billion capital budget is now oil directed. And I'm proud to report that the $1.6 billion remains unchanged since our beginning of year announcement.
Our domestic oil volumes are expected to increase nearly 25% in 2010 over 2009. We've improved our portfolio management and our margins have increased. Better margins are a result of higher returns in the oil plays at constant efforts to lower costs and improve efficiencies and a strong oil and gas hedge position.
Through the optionality of our diversified portfolio of assets, we were able to make improved capital allocation choices while continuing to live within cash flow. And finally, we are committed to building for our future. We have several significant assessments underway that could provide additional options and have a material positive impact on our future.
We continue to look for attractive deals or bolt-ons in our current focus areas and we are steadfast in our focus to build a portfolio that can outperform through the inevitable cycles.
2011, well, it's now just around the corner. So for the remainder of today's call, I would like to focus on 2011 and our assets that will continue to drive our valuation and performance.
Our entire management team spent three days together in an off-site meeting last week working on our initial game plan for 2011. Our collective work product will go to the Board of Directors in early November. So here's a brief summary of our current thoughts.
First, the macro environment will remain challenged. In our view, 2011 will be a challenging environment in E&P. Natural gas supply continues to exceed demand, the domestic rig count, particularly the horizontal gas directed rig count, remains higher than warranted by pure economics.
We recognized this dilemma early enough to build a strong hedge position. We're well insulated by these hedges and have oil opportunities in our portfolio today that are delivering both growth and excellent returns. Next, we'll continue to stay focused on oil over gas. It's oil over gas once again. We'll remain far more constructive on oil than we do natural gas going into 2011.
We will continue to defer significant new investments in our natural gas developments, which are substantially held by production today and require limited drilling to retain our primary turn acreage. The Rocky Mountains will remain the centerpiece of our domestic oil story, and we are confident that we can continue to deliver strong oil growth in 2011.
We are fortunate that our acceleration of oil investments began back in 2009. Because of this, we are guiding toward a 25% increase in our 2010 domestic oil volumes, and a 12% increase on our total company oil volumes. With this, we'll have great momentum on the oil growth as we move into 2011.
Our domestic oil growth stems largely from the mining at Butte field [Monument Butte] and the Williston Basin. A continuing acceleration of our drilling programs here create strong incremental net present value by shortening our full field development cycle.
At Monument Butte, we have optimized our drilling program to drill more wells, more efficiently than previously thought possible. We will drill about 375 wells this year at Monument Butte, and grow production more than 20%.
Our pace today provides us with operational momentum as we enter 2011. Our development drilling continues in the Williston Basin with four operated rigs running today. Three of these rigs are working on our off Anticline acreage. We have successfully assessed our Catwalk, Aquarium and Watford areas west of the Nesson, and have moved these project areas into the development drum phase.
Our assessment phase is focused on 4,000-foot laterals year-to-date. Our IPs for the 17 wells drilled and completed so far in 2010 average about 2,400 barrels of oil equivalent per day. As we transition into development, we plan to drill primarily 9,000-foot long laterals. We are currently drilling or completing five long laterals in our off Anticline acreage and expect to complete our first 32 stage frac job later this month in the Watford area. We will have lots of new information from our Williston program late this year. We continue to be excited about the potential of our acreage and expect that our 2011 Williston Basin net production will exceed 10,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day in late 2011.
Our Granite Wash play in the Mid-Continent region continues to be an active focus area for us as well. The Granite Wash play generates superior economics through a combination of high early flow rates, quick payout and the rich gas condensate that makes up the flow stream. 
In the third quarter, just 3.5% of our total company production came in the form of NGLs. Internationally, our production is 100% oil. We averaged nearly 14,000 barrels of oil per day net in the third quarter and are guiding to 20,000 barrels of oil per day net in the fourth quarter.
In Malaysia, our oil projects are very profitable. Keep in mind that our PACS provide for surety of returns in low price environments, as well as a healthy participation in times like today. We break out our international cost structure separately in our release, so that you can better understand our profitability. Today, we are also developing a new field in Malaysia on PM 329 called East Piatu. This oil development will add about 15,000 barrels of oil per day gross late in 2011. Nearly 70% operating interest in this field, which will allow us to grow our Malaysian production in 2012.
Improving margins, growing cash flow per share will be differentiating factors ahead. More than 60% of our current revenues in 2010 will be derived from our oil volumes. Our V tax rate of returns today in the Williston Basin and Monument Butte range from 50% to 90%. Our Granite Wash play is delivering returns of 20% to 60% depending on the NGL condensate contribution.
There is a chart in our recent handouts that shows our margin improvement over the last two years. This is data pulled from public financials for 18 of our peer companies including our self. We moved from 12th place in 2008 to fourth place today. And today, there's only 2% margin difference in the top four names. If you haven't seen this slide, I encourage you take a look at it.
We are quite proud of this accomplishment. Margins matter and our results can be attributed to aggressive portfolio management, quality oil assets, a diligent focus on cost reduction, optimization where [ph] (0:23:47) drilling the completion programs and a strong hedge position that has added more than $300 million in additional revenues year-to-date.
Natural gas is a great commodity, but not today. Long term, we remain gas fulls [ph]. Natural gas will have a vital role in our domestic energy policy and our energy future. And we will look for ways to improve margins within our gas directed portfolio. It's clean, it's abundant and it's the only logical source of domestic energy that we have to meet our growing future power generation needs.
Short term, we have an oversupply condition. We will continue to slow our investment levels in natural gas place until fundamentals provide reason for acceleration. Let me be clear. We have a substantial Woodford Shale portfolio that is profitable at current low gas prices. And I suspect and most operators in our peer group companies have a sweet spot or two in their gas plays as well and we'll provide them with the same option. But with oil assets delivering superior economics, our investment choice is obvious today. We are focused on oil over gas and delivering profitable growth from oil.
We've reduced our gas drilling activities dramatically. In fact, we are only running four dry gas rigs across the company today. If gas prices continue to remain at low levels, we will allocate even less capital to natural gas in 2011.
As a result of lower levels of investment in natural gas plays, you can see in our financials that our gas production is now declining as expected. We anticipate this will continue into 2011. It's the right choice economically. More than 70% of our gas production is hedged for 2011 at about $6. But we will not subsidize less economic drilling with hedges when we have better alternatives in our portfolio and our focus will continue to be profitable growth through oil.
I'm confident that we can deliver healthy production growth from our domestic oil plays and defer our ramp up in natural gas developments into the future.
Service costs align with today's demand, but not tomorrow's. We've seen significant service cost increases in many of our focus areas, namely the Williston Basin and the Eagle Ford Shale. Cost increases have come in the form of pressure pumping, day rate increases, oil country tubular good price increases. We've seen increases at 15% to 45% in these areas, and economic margins have contracted. We will continue to rely on the size of our operations, the steady nature of our drilling programs and our quality of relationships with key service providers to ensure that we get the most competitive price available in our oil plays.
We also rely on our staff, a team of professionals that continue to impress with an ability to maximize margins through their diligent and creative efforts and the application of technology. 
For 2011, our game plan will be very simple. Number one, focus on oil growth. Number two, maximize our cash margins. Three, provide consistent and predictable results for our shareholders. And four, continue to build for the future.
We are confident that we have the portfolio of assets in place to deliver on our game plan and our proven team Newfield will continue delivering Operational Excellence.
Let me briefly cover our financial results for the quarter. For the third quarter, our earning for FAS 133 were $1.10 per share. Our production for the third quarter was 71 Bcf equivalent and includes the impact of approximately 300,000 barrels of deferred production in Malaysia, related to a damaged export pipeline. Our Malaysian team works hard and fast and the line was repaired and returned to service in four weeks.
Our 2010 capital budget, as I said earlier, remains unchanged at $1.6 billion. Terry Rathert, our CFO, will be happy to take any questions you may have regarding our quarterly results at the end of this call.
Now I'll move on to give you brief highlights on our assessment programs. In addition to our ongoing operations, I highlighted earlier in the call, we have active assessments underway today in several new areas. I will comment today on two of them, the Eagle Ford Shale and the Southern Alberta Basin.
These oil plays have the potential to be game changers in the future for Newfield. The Eagle Ford Shale is one of the hottest plays underway in the U.S. today. We have more than 300,000 net acres in the highly prospective Eagle Ford Shale. And this acreage was added less than one year ago and their very attractive entry costs were approximately $400 per acre.
We're investing about $120 million this year to thoroughly assess our acreage. Our operator rig count has ranged from three to five rigs in recent months and our plans call for 15 wells to be drilled and completed by year end 2010. To date, four of these wells have been completed and turned to sales, and eight of these wells are growing or in various stages of completion today.
As we've consistently stated, we do not plan to make any public announcements about our results until we have comprehensive assessment program completed. We expect to have results to share with you very soon most likely in early 2011. What I can say is that our results today have been consistent with our pre-drill planning and we remain encouraged about the potential of this new area.
We have a similar assessment program underway on our more than 260,000 net acres in the Southern Alberta Basin. We recently TDed our fifth well in this region and have completed our first horizontal well.
We will drill as many as eight wells in our assessment campaigns to test multiple formations across our Southern Alberta acreage block. We're executing our original plan and I'm pleased with our team's operational performance. Again, we will not be discussing individual well results, and we will update you when we have a comprehensive understanding over acreage and its potential.
I'll move on now to talk about the Gulf of Mexico. As you're all aware last week, the moratorium in the Gulf of Mexico was lifted this was a great first step to return our industry back to work in the Gulf.
We have a great track record of safety and environmental stewardship that spans decades. And I am confident that the horrific tragedy at Macondo was an isolated event and not indicative of our industry and more specifically how Newfield operates.  Although the moratorium has lifted, lots of uncertainty remains.  We will carefully review the new rules and regulations. We will carefully assess the implied economic changes and use this information to help determine our path forward in the deep water Gulf of Mexico exploration arena.
In the meantime, our development programs are all on track. Initial gross production from Gladden project is scheduled for December 2010 at about 4,750 barrels of oil per day. We have a 57½% working interest at Gladden. Our Pyrenees project is slated for first production in the fourth quarter of next year and our Dalmatian and Axe projects are currently scheduled to come online in 2013.
In closing, as we enter the homestretch in 2010, I want to reflect on the slide that we provided in our IR presentations at the beginning of the year. We listed our vision for 2010 as follows: Number one, continue to focus on domestic resource plays of scale. We are clearly doing so and are simultaneously assessing two significant plays that cover more than 500,000 net acres. We're also continuing to expand our footprint at the Monument Butte field. We wanted to focus on oil over gas and the proof is in our oil growth numbers for both 2010 and in our expected 2011 oil production volumes.
The second item was harvest assets and optimize the portfolio. We have refueled our conventional South Texas teams to focus on unconventional basins. The cash flow from our conventional assets is helping to fund this transformation. Thirdly, deploy people and capital to the best growth opportunities. From our improvement in margins, the results of capital discipline and more effective capital allocation are readily apparent. Our people are focused on the right assets and on doing the right things right.
Lastly, maintain financial strength. Earlier this year, we retired some term debt and our first maturity is now not until 2014. We were recently upgraded to Investment Grade by S&P. Our balance sheet is strong, our revolver is undrawn and we have one of the most valuable hedge position in oil and gas in our peer group.
I like where we sit today, and I'm truly looking forward to 2011. Thanks for your continued support of Newfield Exploration. That concludes our prepared remarks, and we're happy to take your questions at this time.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And we'll take our first question from Scott Wilmoth with Simmons & Co.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And we'll take our first question from Scott Wilmoth with Simmons & Co.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just on Monument Butte, for a minute you guys mentioned 2011 production growth of 20%. Has there been an improvement in the permitting process there? Or do you guys plan to add a rig there in 2011 to maybe take advantage of an inventory permit you guys ha
componenttext: Just on Monument Butte, for a minute you guys mentioned 2011 production growth of 20%. Has there been an improvement in the permitting process there? Or do you guys plan to add a rig there in 2011 to maybe take advantage of an inventory permit you guys have? Or can you just talk about continued efficiency gains into 2011?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: We've not seen any material change in the permitting status out of Monument Butte. As far as the efficiency gains, I think we communicated earlier this year we're going to produce or drill about 20% more wells than we historically have as a result of the
componenttext: We've not seen any material change in the permitting status out of Monument Butte. As far as the efficiency gains, I think we communicated earlier this year we're going to produce or drill about 20% more wells than we historically have as a result of the gains that we've realized year-to-date. We anticipate those gains will be consistent into 2011, and really don't see any change there. As far as adding an additional rig, a sixth rig is something we have in hip our pocket. I don't anticipate that it'll be funded in the first part of our program, but it's something that we will look at as we move through 2011.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: So the 20% growth does not imply a sixth rig?
componenttext: So the 20% growth does not imply a sixth rig?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: That's correct. We're going to drill about 375 this year. I would suspect we'll be pushing 400 as we look into next year, once we get a full year of those efficiency gains.
componenttext: That's correct. We're going to drill about 375 this year. I would suspect we'll be pushing 400 as we look into next year, once we get a full year of those efficiency gains.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then can you just mention may be improving well results or well results recently versus in the past? And how those are trending?
componenttext: And then can you just mention may be improving well results or well results recently versus in the past? And how those are trending?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think we saw a pretty good increase in well results as we stepped up to the North and got in to some of the areas that hadn't historically been drilled and developed as we moved on some of the Tribal acreage. Those trends still continue. And we still co
componenttext: I think we saw a pretty good increase in well results as we stepped up to the North and got in to some of the areas that hadn't historically been drilled and developed as we moved on some of the Tribal acreage. Those trends still continue. And we still continue to see good results in our 20-acre Infill Program. So no degradation in results in either of those areas.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just in the Williston, it seems like kind of takeaway capacity is nearing constraints out of the basin, we've seen increased rail usage. Can you guys talk about your takeaway agreements or things you have in place to handle the ramp you guys plan
componenttext: And then just in the Williston, it seems like kind of takeaway capacity is nearing constraints out of the basin, we've seen increased rail usage. Can you guys talk about your takeaway agreements or things you have in place to handle the ramp you guys plan in 2011?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. Specifically, we've looked at a couple of different projects. There are opportunities to continue to commit to projects, the Enbridge expansion. There's a bridger baker [ph] (0:35:54) line that's out there. We also have some refinery commitments tha
componenttext: Sure. Specifically, we've looked at a couple of different projects. There are opportunities to continue to commit to projects, the Enbridge expansion. There's a bridger baker [ph] (0:35:54) line that's out there. We also have some refinery commitments that are going to carry us through 2011. And then also as you already suggested, rail is certainly an option that we're looking at in all areas, more favorably than maybe historically we had.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: But all 2011 volumes, you say are committed to refineries at this point?
componenttext: But all 2011 volumes, you say are committed to refineries at this point?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: They're not all committed at this point, pretty close though.
componenttext: They're not all committed at this point, pretty close though.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then you guys talked about in the Bakken well costs obviously, pretty heavy inflation there. Can you talk about the Eagle Ford, the general service environment there and kind of well cost, how those are trended?
componenttext: And then you guys talked about in the Bakken well costs obviously, pretty heavy inflation there. Can you talk about the Eagle Ford, the general service environment there and kind of well cost, how those are trended?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'd rather not talk anything about the Eagle Ford at this point until we can put out all of our numbers down there. I guess, suffice it to say that completion costs certainly are up, relative to the time period that we've entered the play there. We've see
componenttext: I'd rather not talk anything about the Eagle Ford at this point until we can put out all of our numbers down there. I guess, suffice it to say that completion costs certainly are up, relative to the time period that we've entered the play there. We've seen a material increase in drilling activity. And quite honestly, much of this was expected.  Anytime you enter a new basin, whether it's the Southern Alberta Basin or the Maverick Basin where infrastructure and those services don't exist, you can almost anticipate this kind of early increase. I anticipate 2011 as those services come back into the areas. They'll be a lot more readily available, and we'll see some softening in some of those areas, and as we lock in to certain preferred service providers. But you hit the two where we're seeing the most pressure, both in Williston Basin and the Mav Basin, 30%, 40% certainly would not be out of the question.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just lastly, it looks like third quarter domestic oil production came in a little below guidance. Can you just talk about what might have led that?
componenttext: And then just lastly, it looks like third quarter domestic oil production came in a little below guidance. Can you just talk about what might have led that?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. Probably, it's best described as three things. As we entered the winter market, the Salt Lake City refineries typically enter in a turnaround period, whether converted to their winter diesels, which have different cost point.  Two of our refineries
componenttext: Sure. Probably, it's best described as three things. As we entered the winter market, the Salt Lake City refineries typically enter in a turnaround period, whether converted to their winter diesels, which have different cost point.  Two of our refineries encountered that, and we'll be encountering that as we move into the fourth quarter. So that's interrupted some of the volumes that will result in a build of inventory that we would anticipate taking out the first quarter. And then also, related to your prior question, on the completions in the Williston Basin. I'd say, through the bulk of 2010, we were sitting at about 25 days or so when we took the well from TD to being placed on production. We've seen that slide as activities increase today. We'll probably sitting at about 45 or 50 days. And we've anticipated in the fourth quarter that, that number could expand a little bit due to the winter conditions, as well as some of the pressure on services. Again, we'll see that improve as we move into the first quarter. And then maybe, finally, anytime we step into these assessment programs early on, takeaway capacity is a little less predictable. As a result of that, infrastructure has to keep up with your completions. And that's probably been a minor amount of the difference. But at the end of the day, I think we're only talking about 200,000 barrels or so.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And we'll move on to our next question from Gil Yang with Bank of America.
componenttext: And we'll move on to our next question from Gil Yang with Bank of America.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Could you comment on the international sequential expected pick up in oil volumes? It sounds like about 50%. Obviously, the pipeline coming back on is part of that, but what are the other components of that growth?
componenttext: Could you comment on the international sequential expected pick up in oil volumes? It sounds like about 50%. Obviously, the pipeline coming back on is part of that, but what are the other components of that growth?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, a lot of that, Gil, is just the timing of liftings. We've built some capacity in the tanks as we were down there for a while. And we've just scheduled our liftings here recently for the fourth quarter and we're going to take two material liftings in
componenttext: Yes, a lot of that, Gil, is just the timing of liftings. We've built some capacity in the tanks as we were down there for a while. And we've just scheduled our liftings here recently for the fourth quarter and we're going to take two material liftings in November/December. And then with that, I guess, operationally, the debottlenecking that we did at PM 323 has been very successful. The team's done a great job. Not only in returning that pipeline to production but also maximizing the production out of our East Belumut field.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: So in a way we can think of the fourth quarter as being a make up for the shortfall in the third quarter?
componenttext: So in a way we can think of the fourth quarter as being a make up for the shortfall in the third quarter?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: To a minor degree, part of that is going to be the carryover. But we also have an increase in sustainable production out of East Belumut in PM 323. So I'm optimistic there and as Lee referenced this in his call, as we look into 2011, the East Piatu field
componenttext: To a minor degree, part of that is going to be the carryover. But we also have an increase in sustainable production out of East Belumut in PM 323. So I'm optimistic there and as Lee referenced this in his call, as we look into 2011, the East Piatu field will be coming on I believe in October of next year, which should give us another little bump in production as we look year-on-year internationally.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: So of the roughly 6,000 barrels per day, increase sequentially. How much of that is the sustainable growth portion? And how much is the makeup portion from the third quarter for fall?
componenttext: So of the roughly 6,000 barrels per day, increase sequentially. How much of that is the sustainable growth portion? And how much is the makeup portion from the third quarter for fall?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'd say off the top of my head, Gil, we're properly looking at about 2,000 to 3,000 barrels a day is what we've seen as an increase out of PM 323, and the balance would just be lifting schedules.
componenttext: Yes, I'd say off the top of my head, Gil, we're properly looking at about 2,000 to 3,000 barrels a day is what we've seen as an increase out of PM 323, and the balance would just be lifting schedules.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And is that 2,000/3,000 barrel increase versus the third quarter sustainable until the October Piatu ramp up?
componenttext: And is that 2,000/3,000 barrel increase versus the third quarter sustainable until the October Piatu ramp up?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's going to be well dependent. We've got a drilling campaign and a rig committed in 2011. So notionally, I would say yes. And we also -- I mean, the other, I guess the other one I did leave out, West Belumut is now online. We have a couple of wells ther
componenttext: It's going to be well dependent. We've got a drilling campaign and a rig committed in 2011. So notionally, I would say yes. And we also -- I mean, the other, I guess the other one I did leave out, West Belumut is now online. We have a couple of wells there that are performing well. But as you know, that also is into the same pipeline system, which ultimately defines how much our takeaway is from PM 323.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And could you comment on the costs of your wells in the Bakken? They seem to be running higher than, materially higher than what some of your competitors to the North would say their wells are costing. Can you comment on, do you think that that's the case
componenttext: And could you comment on the costs of your wells in the Bakken? They seem to be running higher than, materially higher than what some of your competitors to the North would say their wells are costing. Can you comment on, do you think that that's the case? Or are you talking about apples-and-oranges in the way you've talked about cost or do you think your costs can come down?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, I can't really comment on what the competitors of North are saying. I'm not sure what companies and what type of well designs that we're talking about. I'd say historically, our well costs out there have been their competitive with industry
componenttext: Well, I mean, I can't really comment on what the competitors of North are saying. I'm not sure what companies and what type of well designs that we're talking about. I'd say historically, our well costs out there have been their competitive with industry activity. Historically, we've been out there drilling these 4,000-foot laterals and the results that we've posted on our website are all consistent with those shorter laterals. And I think those well costs at $5.5 million or so are very reasonable. Now as we head into the longer laterals, and I think in the call, we referenced about an $8 million well cost. To be clear, we have not drilled and completed a 9,000-foot lateral yet. So some of that is an estimation of what we will spend at this point in time with the higher completion costs factored in. Absolutely, as I look into next year, I would anticipate our team as we drill the 9,000-foot laterals, 32-stage completions, we'll be able to push back on those costs. While I have a whole lot of information on the shorter laterals that we could talk about, the higher end cost there of $7.5 million to $8 million is an estimate in the current croppy market that we see in the Williston.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then finally, if I look at the results to guide on your operational press release, you've got some really good wells, some wells that are sort of okay. But they tend to be sort of similarly clustered in the Aquarium/Watford area. I know it's a small s
componenttext: And then finally, if I look at the results to guide on your operational press release, you've got some really good wells, some wells that are sort of okay. But they tend to be sort of similarly clustered in the Aquarium/Watford area. I know it's a small sample set, but do you think that -- are you're seeing any trends there with those IP results? Or is it just more the randomness of the sampling?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think it's the randomness of the sampling to a great degree. If you actually go back and look at the well results that we saw in the Westberg and Lost Bear area, we saw a steady increase and improvement in well results over time due to the tweaking of o
componenttext: I think it's the randomness of the sampling to a great degree. If you actually go back and look at the well results that we saw in the Westberg and Lost Bear area, we saw a steady increase and improvement in well results over time due to the tweaking of our completion practices. Kind of the average wells that you referenced are still 1,800, 2,000 barrels a day IP. The area that we don't and have not posted a lot of well results, personally, is in the Catwalk area. And I know we identified it as a development phase. We've now drilled, I believe two or three wells in Catwalk. We're just completing them at this time. But there's been eight wells drilled by industry across the acreage position that kind of has given us a lot of confidence in what those well results will be. So I wouldn't read too much into some of those IP's at this point. Kind of let us drill a few more wells and then we'll report on what we think.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Gil, I would add to that, if you go back and look at the earlier results that we announced say in our first year, year and a half of assessment, when we went back towards some of those early wells and drilled offsets, we were 2x on the results.  So you ca
componenttext: Gil, I would add to that, if you go back and look at the earlier results that we announced say in our first year, year and a half of assessment, when we went back towards some of those early wells and drilled offsets, we were 2x on the results.  So you can clearly see the learnings captured by our Williston Basin team being applied to the wells, and those are immediate offsets. So I think that's what I would look to, to go ahead and get you to feel good and kind of help understand. We can't change the sample set size at this point. We got four rigs running. We're drilling as fast as we can.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: So in that context though, do you think that -- are there significant differences on what you see geologically in Aquarium and Watford that would allow you to -- I mean, these are the first -- these appear [ph] (0:46:10) that they're drilling small sample
componenttext: So in that context though, do you think that -- are there significant differences on what you see geologically in Aquarium and Watford that would allow you to -- I mean, these are the first -- these appear [ph] (0:46:10) that they're drilling small samples out there. Do you think that maybe the wells will get better as you learn more about that area? Is it different enough from Westburg that there's things you need to learn about?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Absolutely. And we've seen this in every one of the resource plays that we enter. You establish that early EUR and IP and well costs and we have consistently been able to prove on each of those as we drill more wells. I fully expect that, that'll be the c
componenttext: Absolutely. And we've seen this in every one of the resource plays that we enter. You establish that early EUR and IP and well costs and we have consistently been able to prove on each of those as we drill more wells. I fully expect that, that'll be the case here as well. And again, I'm not apologizing for the well results that we see right now because they're quite profitable and we have three rigs dedicated to drilling more oil.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And so there's enough variability, it's about 20 miles down the road. So there's no variability there that you may need to do things differently there?
componenttext: And so there's enough variability, it's about 20 miles down the road. So there's no variability there that you may need to do things differently there?

componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Joe Allman with JPMorgan.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Joe Allman with JPMorgan.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Recently, we heard an energy comment about the Eagle Ford Shale and in particular, in Maverick County that the oil out there is heavy. Could you guys comment on sort of the quality of oil? And any other issues you need to deal with out there in the Eagle
componenttext: Recently, we heard an energy comment about the Eagle Ford Shale and in particular, in Maverick County that the oil out there is heavy. Could you guys comment on sort of the quality of oil? And any other issues you need to deal with out there in the Eagle Ford?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: There is heavy oil in the Maverick Basin. As people read their research papers a little closely, they'll find that it's bitumen and it's shallow and has nothing to do whatsoever with the targeted Eagle Ford section that we're testing. I would simply say t
componenttext: There is heavy oil in the Maverick Basin. As people read their research papers a little closely, they'll find that it's bitumen and it's shallow and has nothing to do whatsoever with the targeted Eagle Ford section that we're testing. I would simply say that we've got a policy of not talking about what other people are doing and offering our thoughts. And I would appreciate frankly if some of our peers that want to pontificate about things that they know nothing about, might stick to their plays and you wait for Newfield to say about what's going on in the Maverick Basin. I said we're encouraged and I said that we're continuing with our program. And frankly, I'm excited about what we're seeing. And I look forward to talking to you guys early in the New Year.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just moving on to a different topic. In the Arkoma Woodford, so do I hear you correctly that assuming if gas prices stay where they are, you would expect to drop some rigs there in the Arkoma Woodford?
componenttext: And then just moving on to a different topic. In the Arkoma Woodford, so do I hear you correctly that assuming if gas prices stay where they are, you would expect to drop some rigs there in the Arkoma Woodford?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, Gary has been managing that all through the year. I'll let him speak to it here in a moment. But we started the year in Woodford at nine rigs. And we've added some acreage over the course of the last year in Woodford, our total acreage count's up to
componenttext: Well, Gary has been managing that all through the year. I'll let him speak to it here in a moment. But we started the year in Woodford at nine rigs. And we've added some acreage over the course of the last year in Woodford, our total acreage count's up to around 172,000. So we do have a small component at non-HBP acreage. We can handle the non-HBP acreage with about one rig. We've been trying to balance out. We feel the responsibility in our main operating areas to work with our service providers and the other people that are all part of the development activities. We're trying to balance the needs of a healthy service environment with our desire to shift towards oil, and we're rapidly accelerating in that regard. But we've got from nine rigs to four rigs today. The statement was made that if gas prices continue to stay very soft or deteriorate further, we'll continue to rotate rigs out of the dry gas portion of our portfolio into the oily components. The four rigs, the four dry gas rigs that we have running are drilling super extended lateral wells into Woodford. And we've told you guys, we've got a good strong core position there and those SXL wells work. And we've got a portfolio, but we prefer the margins that we see in oil. And we're going to continue to monitor that situation and be nimble with regard to our responses. But I'll let Gary add any other color he might have.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Joe. I think guess the only thing I'd add is I think the Mid-Con team has done a great job, high grading the Woodford. And we could continue to maintain a reasonable level of activity out there, and still drill returns that we're proud of in the Wood
componenttext: Yes, Joe. I think guess the only thing I'd add is I think the Mid-Con team has done a great job, high grading the Woodford. And we could continue to maintain a reasonable level of activity out there, and still drill returns that we're proud of in the Woodford Shale. It's just a matter of the fact that we've got these incremental opportunities and it's our commitment that we live with the cash flow. That is only the restrictor on our capital investments out there. I think it's important that we maintain a relatively consistent level of activity in each of our areas not only for the benefit of the key service providers that we've aligned ourselves with, but also to maintain this trajectory of efficiency gains that we've referred to a few times this morning. You can't take a program back to nothing and expect to capture those when you ramp back up again. So yes, I would anticipate a slowdown in the Woodford capital allocation. But we'll still have a material present there. And we will be in a position when gas prices do rally and they will, that we'll be able to drive very profitable growth out there long into the future.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then lastly just a different topic on, back to the service cost issue. So going into 2011, what are your assumptions on your well costs? Do you expect them to be higher in 2011 from where they are now? Or flat or down because of efficiencies?
componenttext: And then lastly just a different topic on, back to the service cost issue. So going into 2011, what are your assumptions on your well costs? Do you expect them to be higher in 2011 from where they are now? Or flat or down because of efficiencies?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think we've done a great job of pushing back on much of the increases this year as a result of the efficiencies we've had. I think it'd be fair to say that if I look across the tour we made of each of our business units, two weeks ago, that we're p
componenttext: Yes, I think we've done a great job of pushing back on much of the increases this year as a result of the efficiencies we've had. I think it'd be fair to say that if I look across the tour we made of each of our business units, two weeks ago, that we're probably looking at somewhere around 10% or 15% depending on the area, that have already been kind of built into our capital projections for 2011 on the drilling side. Some areas have been able to actually hold the line and we're looking at flat into next year. As you know, much of this will be dependent upon the role of the rigs and how much new horsepower is coming on, on the completion side.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And when you say 10% to 15% up in 2011 in some areas is that from right now or is that from the average of 2010?
componenttext: And when you say 10% to 15% up in 2011 in some areas is that from right now or is that from the average of 2010?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I would say that's probably from earlier this year, or maybe an average of 2010. So much of that's already been baked in. So as you look into 2011, as approxi [approximately], it would probably be flat to where we sit here in the third, fourth quarter.
componenttext: I would say that's probably from earlier this year, or maybe an average of 2010. So much of that's already been baked in. So as you look into 2011, as approxi [approximately], it would probably be flat to where we sit here in the third, fourth quarter.

componenttextpreview: Clarification on the production growth out of Monument Butte. I thought the 20% was this year and when we look at the 20,000 barrels a day, you'll exit this year out, that's already up 20% over the average for this year. So I guess by the end of next year
componenttext: Clarification on the production growth out of Monument Butte. I thought the 20% was this year and when we look at the 20,000 barrels a day, you'll exit this year out, that's already up 20% over the average for this year. So I guess by the end of next year, what would you expect that 20,000 barrels a day in the Monument Butte to grow to?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: When we look out at -- and it depends on what our capital allocation is, of course, but I would like to see and would expect to see somewhere in the order of 28,000 to 30,000 barrels a day gross, with the appropriate expectation depending on capital inves
componenttext: When we look out at -- and it depends on what our capital allocation is, of course, but I would like to see and would expect to see somewhere in the order of 28,000 to 30,000 barrels a day gross, with the appropriate expectation depending on capital investment out there for year at the end of 2011.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: In the Woodford, you had stated earlier this year that the typical well required 450 gas to get a 10% full cycle rate of return. And in fact, a year ago, when natural gas prices are actually slightly better than what they are today, you curtailed about th
componenttext: In the Woodford, you had stated earlier this year that the typical well required 450 gas to get a 10% full cycle rate of return. And in fact, a year ago, when natural gas prices are actually slightly better than what they are today, you curtailed about three Bcf of production out of the Woodford. So has that breakeven cost come down and what is it now? And are costs at a level that today even with gas prices close to what they were a year ago, you would not or would now be looking at perhaps again shutting in production?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we shut the production in last year in response to market conditions. So you're exactly right. The decision was made last year when gas hit a two handle is when we made the decision. So we took the three Bcf net out and it was a decision we made, an
componenttext: Well, we shut the production in last year in response to market conditions. So you're exactly right. The decision was made last year when gas hit a two handle is when we made the decision. So we took the three Bcf net out and it was a decision we made, and we signal the market and all of the above. I would tell you that the issues in terms of performance relative to the core, we've seen exceptional performance in terms of continued efficiency gains out of our team in the Mid-Con. So we've actually been able to improve the metrics on our super extended laterals. And that's all that we're drilling today. So we've got super extended laterals in the core of the Woodford Shale are the wells that are being drilled. And in that regard, year-over-year, there is an improvement all up in those well costs and F&D cost improvement and therefore, slightly lower threshold. But I would say that the 400 to 450 is not a bad range to be thinking about Woodford Shale, 10% plus V tax.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Today's price of $350, you're not considering shutting in any production? Or where would you consider that again?
componenttext: Today's price of $350, you're not considering shutting in any production? Or where would you consider that again?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: We haven't got a specific target price, Joe. It's something that we monitor and talk about on an ongoing basis. And we'll just monitor the situation and make the decision as we see fit at the time. But $350, with our hedge position, we see no need to curt
componenttext: We haven't got a specific target price, Joe. It's something that we monitor and talk about on an ongoing basis. And we'll just monitor the situation and make the decision as we see fit at the time. But $350, with our hedge position, we see no need to curtail production at this point.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010

componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Joe Magner with Macquarie Capital.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to touch base on the horizontal Granite Wash is more of a hybrid or liquids rich gas opportunity, how did the economics of the projects back up relative to the some other pure play oil projects?
componenttext: Just wanted to touch base on the horizontal Granite Wash is more of a hybrid or liquids rich gas opportunity, how did the economics of the projects back up relative to the some other pure play oil projects?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'd say, if we were just going to look at a portfolio of wells in each of our areas, I would say that we're sitting there at Monument Butte being earning best returns, Williston Basin the second. And then as we move the next -- and I'm not talking about o
componenttext: I'd say, if we were just going to look at a portfolio of wells in each of our areas, I would say that we're sitting there at Monument Butte being earning best returns, Williston Basin the second. And then as we move the next -- and I'm not talking about our assessment plays at this point, I'm just focus on development plays. It would be the Granite Wash, specifically the Marmaton. I would say that the Marmaton drilling in the Granite Wash competes favorably improbably, and probably right behind our Williston program. And as referenced earlier, if it continues to see cost pressures, it may depending on the well that we'd select it could actually, maybe rise above that. And then this would be followed by the Atoka drilling. So I'd say generically, V tax, today you could probably see as much as a 50%, 60% return, if we drill Britt [ph] (0:57:15) like wells targeting the proven Marmaton section.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: With all that being said, do you anticipate 2011 activity levels to be changed materially from where they were for this year up or down? Some of that's gas price dependent but how should we think about that?
componenttext: With all that being said, do you anticipate 2011 activity levels to be changed materially from where they were for this year up or down? Some of that's gas price dependent but how should we think about that?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I wouldn't say materially.  We have four rigs running in the wash right now. I'd say George would say that, that probably feels pretty good and then any reduction there would only be because we have a superior investment opportunity somewhere else. B
componenttext: Yes, I wouldn't say materially.  We have four rigs running in the wash right now. I'd say George would say that, that probably feels pretty good and then any reduction there would only be because we have a superior investment opportunity somewhere else. But I just, I couldn't see them getting below three rigs.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: In the Woodford Shale, you've talked about SXLs are the only wells you're drilling now. It looks like the average length came down for the wells that have been drilled to date this year from where it was in the second quarter. Is there anything in particu
componenttext: In the Woodford Shale, you've talked about SXLs are the only wells you're drilling now. It looks like the average length came down for the wells that have been drilled to date this year from where it was in the second quarter. Is there anything in particular that's driving that change?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don't know what you're looking at in terms of the accounting. I'll let George jump in here in a second. But the last tally that we saw, we just came through on our quarterly review tour. And we were up year-over-year in terms of the total delivered leng
componenttext: I don't know what you're looking at in terms of the accounting. I'll let George jump in here in a second. But the last tally that we saw, we just came through on our quarterly review tour. And we were up year-over-year in terms of the total delivered length in accordance with our plan. I would say that 7,000 feet is a number that you ought to probably be thinking about in terms of delivered length on those wells versus whatever the comparison is that you're looking at. That square, George?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: That's accurate. I would say, obviously, anywhere we can we try to get north of 9,000 feet. And generally, what would shorten the lateral length would be faulting geologic conditions. So they'd range from 5,000 to 9,000. But generally, most everything, so
componenttext: That's accurate. I would say, obviously, anywhere we can we try to get north of 9,000 feet. And generally, what would shorten the lateral length would be faulting geologic conditions. So they'd range from 5,000 to 9,000. But generally, most everything, some of the average, I'm not sure where he's getting the number either, maybe wells earlier in the year. Almost the thing now has been in the 8,000-plus recently.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Joe, I'd follow up with Steve and we can get you tied up. So you've got the accurate up-to-date numbers there.
componenttext: Yes, Joe, I'd follow up with Steve and we can get you tied up. So you've got the accurate up-to-date numbers there.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Ok, I'll follow up. It looked like it was 8,800 in the second quarter Ops update and 8,400 in the third quarter. And then 2010, you've been committed to living within cash flow. It sounds like you're going to be maintaining that sort of philosophy. With t
componenttext: Ok, I'll follow up. It looked like it was 8,800 in the second quarter Ops update and 8,400 in the third quarter. And then 2010, you've been committed to living within cash flow. It sounds like you're going to be maintaining that sort of philosophy. With the cost inflation you've experienced that you have factored in for next year, do you think you'd be able to absorb those with efficiencies and other offsets to be able to maintain that same sort of strategy going into next year?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Joe, we do. Our plan it's two-fold. We bake in a little bit of the cost increases that we've already talked about year-to-date. It is our full expectation that we will be live [ph] (1:00:13) within cash flow and we'll still deliver good growth number
componenttext: Yes, Joe, we do. Our plan it's two-fold. We bake in a little bit of the cost increases that we've already talked about year-to-date. It is our full expectation that we will be live [ph] (1:00:13) within cash flow and we'll still deliver good growth numbers into next year. So it's a combination of the efficiency gains. But it's also a comment on the quality of the assets that we plan to allocate capital to next year.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then it looks like a couple of pieces you've provided some 2011 growth expectations out of the Williston and Monument Butte, when do you think you'll have a comprehensive plan put together?
componenttext: And then it looks like a couple of pieces you've provided some 2011 growth expectations out of the Williston and Monument Butte, when do you think you'll have a comprehensive plan put together?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I'm going to hope that I don't get in too much trouble with the Board. We said we met last week and we're giving you guys color on our thoughts for 2011. We haven't even talked to the Board, so they're hearing some of these at the same time you guys
componenttext: Well, I'm going to hope that I don't get in too much trouble with the Board. We said we met last week and we're giving you guys color on our thoughts for 2011. We haven't even talked to the Board, so they're hearing some of these at the same time you guys are. We're going to stick with our normal cycle. You'll hear our thoughts and opinions early in the new year and we'll lay them out in detail for you at that time.

componenttext: The short answer is yes.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think if you read the operational release that we put out, it'll be a pretty good guide for you in terms of what we're focused on. The Rockies is the dominant piece of oil story today, so we've shifted capital all year to the Rockies. Mid-Con region is
componenttext: I think if you read the operational release that we put out, it'll be a pretty good guide for you in terms of what we're focused on. The Rockies is the dominant piece of oil story today, so we've shifted capital all year to the Rockies. Mid-Con region is the dominant portion of our gas portfolio today. So it's been giving up capital in preference to investments in the Rockies. So that's probably the best guide I could give you and I wouldn't want to go into any more detail on the individual assets.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010

componenttext: And we'll move on to our next question from Brian Singer with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: In the Granite Wash, can you give us an update on well costs and how you're thinking about the total number of well locations you have to drill on the 46,000 acres when you consider spacing and the multiple horizons?
componenttext: In the Granite Wash, can you give us an update on well costs and how you're thinking about the total number of well locations you have to drill on the 46,000 acres when you consider spacing and the multiple horizons?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: George?
componenttext: George?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well costs are -- well, I guess to use what Gary said earlier, we expect 10% to 15% increase into next year of total well cost. But otherwise, they've remained pretty flat through this year. So that's just a projection. Total number of wells, if we includ
componenttext: Well costs are -- well, I guess to use what Gary said earlier, we expect 10% to 15% increase into next year of total well cost. But otherwise, they've remained pretty flat through this year. So that's just a projection. Total number of wells, if we include both the liquids and the gas portion, it's a lot. It depends on gas prices, et cetera. Where we'll get to. What we've stated typically is 250 plus wells for sure. And you can probably double or triple that as we go-forward and prove up all the horizons.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And is it the multiple horizons that are the sticky points here in terms of getting to a much higher number than 250? Or is it more of the aerial extent and what percent of your acreage as perspective?
componenttext: And is it the multiple horizons that are the sticky points here in terms of getting to a much higher number than 250? Or is it more of the aerial extent and what percent of your acreage as perspective?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's assessing the rest of acreage along with, I guess, our 250 numbers fix in a range of ensuring excellent returns that kind of current gas prices $4 to $5 as you go north of that, more and more stuff will prove up.
componenttext: Yes, it's assessing the rest of acreage along with, I guess, our 250 numbers fix in a range of ensuring excellent returns that kind of current gas prices $4 to $5 as you go north of that, more and more stuff will prove up.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And Brian, the way I would think about is we set out the beginning of this year to increase the number of individual horizons that we've tested. At this point, George has successfully tested nine of nine, where we've drilled horizontal wells out there. We
componenttext: And Brian, the way I would think about is we set out the beginning of this year to increase the number of individual horizons that we've tested. At this point, George has successfully tested nine of nine, where we've drilled horizontal wells out there. We expect that we'll have the tenth horizon tested before year end. I think it is that assessment program that drives the absolute well count in terms of thinking about the inventory. Clearly, the Marmaton, the shallower zones are the liquid rich zones, and we've told you on many occasions, previously the Atoka's dry gas, it's about 1,100 bp of gas and the Marmaton is 1,300 plus with kind of condensate and NGLs. So I think we're executing our plan as we told you. And I agree with George's assessment in terms of the likely well count.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: To delicately go towards the Eagle Ford here, you mentioned in your comments that everything you're seeing is consistent with your pre-drill planning. Can you give us some color on what your pre-drill planning was in terms of the split between oil, gas an
componenttext: To delicately go towards the Eagle Ford here, you mentioned in your comments that everything you're seeing is consistent with your pre-drill planning. Can you give us some color on what your pre-drill planning was in terms of the split between oil, gas and NGLs and the quality of the oil?

componenttext: Brian, I'd like to defer to early next year when we lay all of the details out for that play, if you'll forgive me.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then lastly, if you maintain your current natural gas rig count, is the quarter-on-quarter decline that you're guiding to for 4Q versus 3Q representative of what we'd continue to see over the course of 2011?
componenttext: And then lastly, if you maintain your current natural gas rig count, is the quarter-on-quarter decline that you're guiding to for 4Q versus 3Q representative of what we'd continue to see over the course of 2011?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Brian, I think it is. We've identified the decline but it's very shallow as you've already seen when we look companywide. As we look quarter on quarter, I think we finished the third quarter about 50.5 Bs or so. We've guided just somewhere maybe a B
componenttext: Yes, Brian, I think it is. We've identified the decline but it's very shallow as you've already seen when we look companywide. As we look quarter on quarter, I think we finished the third quarter about 50.5 Bs or so. We've guided just somewhere maybe a B down on the quarter. I think that's representative as we look into next year.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Rehan Rashid from FBR Capital Markets.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Rehan Rashid from FBR Capital Markets.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Going back to the Monument Butte for a quick second, two questions. One, refinery capacity, I know you guys say, you've got 85% kind of spoken for. As you go to 2011, should we be comfortable that further growth will be there in terms of refinery capacity
componenttext: Going back to the Monument Butte for a quick second, two questions. One, refinery capacity, I know you guys say, you've got 85% kind of spoken for. As you go to 2011, should we be comfortable that further growth will be there in terms of refinery capacity?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: As we look into 2011, Rehan, we know that the Holly hydrocracker is fully operational. I think it came back online in July earlier this year. Tesoro is actually seeing and pushing the limits of the systems that they have in place, which should gain us a l
componenttext: As we look into 2011, Rehan, we know that the Holly hydrocracker is fully operational. I think it came back online in July earlier this year. Tesoro is actually seeing and pushing the limits of the systems that they have in place, which should gain us a little bit more capacity. The other thing that we're looking at out there is rail. That is certainly an option for us. Historically, we can all go back several years and it was kind of a last minute and we saw that this differentials attributed to rail are relatively high. But we're looking at it from a longer range planning view and I think it presents an opportunity that's more cost-effective than maybe what it historically was thought to be. And that's another option for us right now. When you start looking out into 2012 and 2013, certainly, we're going to be working with our joint venture partners and our refiner partners up in Salt Lake City to make more material commitments in expansions. But we're confident that there's another 10% or 15% out there to come.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And on the Monument Butte. Were there some thoughts on trying a horizontal well there? And if so, any result, if not, the plans?
componenttext: And on the Monument Butte. Were there some thoughts on trying a horizontal well there? And if so, any result, if not, the plans?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: We're constantly looking at the horizontal wells. I hate to get into discussions of specific wells that we drill in a field as broad as this. But the answer is yes. We do see that as an option for us. We see it's applicability. But as you well know, just
componenttext: We're constantly looking at the horizontal wells. I hate to get into discussions of specific wells that we drill in a field as broad as this. But the answer is yes. We do see that as an option for us. We see it's applicability. But as you well know, just due to the distribution of the formation out there, I wouldn't describe it as having broad application. But in certain areas, in certain parts of the field, I think it does have application and it's something that we're certainly investigating.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And we have another question this time from Dan McSpirit with BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: And we have another question this time from Dan McSpirit with BMO Capital Markets.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Looking at your Bakken producers, when will you need to bring these wells on pump if you haven't already for the earliest wells drilled? And what choke size are you swelling these wells at, at least generally?
componenttext: Looking at your Bakken producers, when will you need to bring these wells on pump if you haven't already for the earliest wells drilled? And what choke size are you swelling these wells at, at least generally?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Every time I bring choke size up everybody says  32/64. So I'm going to play this 32/64 card. I think each one of these wells varies a little different.  It depends on the area. Many of these wells we've already snubbed in tubing and are currently flowing
componenttext: Every time I bring choke size up everybody says  32/64. So I'm going to play this 32/64 card. I think each one of these wells varies a little different.  It depends on the area. Many of these wells we've already snubbed in tubing and are currently flowing up tubing. But it's area specific. It has to do with GURs. And so there isn't a preset pond that we go ahead and place these wells on pumps. Some sooner than others.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And forgive me if this question was already asked and answered. But looking at the Granite Wash and the Marmaton specifically as a targeted horizon, what's been tested in terms of spacing? And what will be tested maybe in 2011 going forward?
componenttext: And forgive me if this question was already asked and answered. But looking at the Granite Wash and the Marmaton specifically as a targeted horizon, what's been tested in terms of spacing? And what will be tested maybe in 2011 going forward?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: George, you want to take that?
componenttext: George, you want to take that?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, generally, we're looking at 200 to 300 acre spacing basically is what's been tested. And at this point, probably, the 200 to 250 looks like it's probably adequate. And it could depend. It's a big area. And rock properties change some throughout the
componenttext: Well, generally, we're looking at 200 to 300 acre spacing basically is what's been tested. And at this point, probably, the 200 to 250 looks like it's probably adequate. And it could depend. It's a big area. And rock properties change some throughout the area. So there could be variances in how we space north to south, east to west.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010

componenttext: Just turning to the Southern Alberta Basin recognizing that any questions here will likely not get answered. But you do list the four perspective formations or horizons in the press release. Are you targeting all four with the eights wells planned? Or was there a single branch [ph] (1:11:26) or single target that's the focus?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, every one of the -- we just TDed our fourth well specifically on the vertical side. And they do test and see the entire perspective section. As Steve referenced in the operational report, we have drilled one horizontal and we just selected one of tho
componenttext: Yes, every one of the -- we just TDed our fourth well specifically on the vertical side. And they do test and see the entire perspective section. As Steve referenced in the operational report, we have drilled one horizontal and we just selected one of those zones for our initial test. And we're evaluating the results of that before we make any other commitments on horizontal. And I prefer not to discuss the specific target of that well.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Appreciating your emphasis, your focus on oil versus gas. But does the outlook ever get so negative in 2011, maybe where you have a repeat of 2010 where you become a buyer of assets, that is natural gas assets in a way to create more option value the opti
componenttext: Appreciating your emphasis, your focus on oil versus gas. But does the outlook ever get so negative in 2011, maybe where you have a repeat of 2010 where you become a buyer of assets, that is natural gas assets in a way to create more option value the option value I see maybe in the Woodford?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, that's a very good question. We've talked a lot over the course of the last year about portfolio model that how we built and how we're using it to help manage the business day-to-day. I think if you go back and look at Newfield's history, we've made
componenttext: Well, that's a very good question. We've talked a lot over the course of the last year about portfolio model that how we built and how we're using it to help manage the business day-to-day. I think if you go back and look at Newfield's history, we've made a number of strategic moves on off cycle periods when the market's not frothy. Frankly, we like the look of gas and frothy oil market in terms of adding to the portfolio. But our mission is going to be the same. Nothing will be added to the Newfield's portfolio that can't compete at the front of the line. I think that's a healthy perspective for us to have and that's the guidance that we give our hunters that are out there chasing opportunities everyday of the week. We ended this year saying that we were going to continue to build for the future, and I've already told you we're going to continue to keep that focus for 2011. So I would say that yes, we're going to be pretty opportunistic looking at the right types of gas opportunities in a soft market.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010

componenttext: Well, I think the earlier comments were simply to remind everybody that those things that make sense in and around the areas where we exist, we're going to be in the market and chasing the right types of opportunities.
