componenttext: And we’ll take our next question from Jack Aydin with KeyBanc Capital Markets.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Hi, guys, thanks. Most of my question was answered, but I do have a follow up on the Alberta Bakken. Of the eight wells that you're planning to drill there, how far apart you drilling these wells from each other?
componenttext: Hi, guys, thanks. Most of my question was answered, but I do have a follow up on the Alberta Bakken. Of the eight wells that you're planning to drill there, how far apart you drilling these wells from each other?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: The - first of all let me - when we refer to it is as this SAB, it’s the Southern Alberta Basin and not the Southern Alberta Bakken. We see the horizon is much broader than just any one specific horizon. As far as the spacing goes, our first three wel
componenttext:
The - first of all let me - when we refer to it is as this SAB, it’s the Southern Alberta Basin and not the Southern Alberta Bakken. We see the horizon is much broader than just any one specific horizon. 
As far as the spacing goes, our first three wells were all within about six miles or so I believe as we sequentially stepped down dip in the formation as our fourth well is considerably - I don’t have a map in front of me, but it probably approaches 20 miles when we stepped - stepped into our last location.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: At this early stage, what kind of costs or what are you looking at? I mean I understand those are science wells, but initially what kind of costs are you looking at?
componenttext: At this early stage, what kind of costs or what are you looking at? I mean I understand those are science wells, but initially what kind of costs are you looking at?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, it just doesn’t make any sense to really talk about the wells that we’re drilling today, because as you mentioned they are science wells and vertical wells, we've got exotic log suites, we're cutting cores, it's not reflective of the type of wel
componenttext: Well, it just doesn’t make any sense to really talk about the wells that we’re drilling today, because as you mentioned they are science wells and vertical wells, we've got exotic log suites, we're cutting cores, it's not reflective of the type of well that we would even be thinking about drilling in a development mode. So it just doesn’t add to the discussion in my opinion today.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, thank you.
componenttext: Okay, thank you.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: You’re welcome.
componenttext: You’re welcome.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And our final question comes from TJ Schultz with RBC Capital.
componenttext: And our final question comes from TJ Schultz with RBC Capital.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning, guys. Just on the Monument Butte, I know you said well performance is looking good as you move north and it looks like you've tested about 25% of the northern extension. Just wondering if you've seen any variance in performance as you kind o
componenttext: Good morning, guys. Just on the Monument Butte, I know you said well performance is looking good as you move north and it looks like you've tested about 25% of the northern extension. Just wondering if you've seen any variance in performance as you kind of move away from the border with the greater Monument Butte Field, and at this point with that 25%, if you've tested yet the kind of four corners of the northern extension?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: The answer as we step north of Monument Butte, we step out of the historic area that’s been drilled and water flooded and we continue to enjoy great success. But as we do that, we get a little deeper in the geologic section. We have a little bit more pr
componenttext:
The answer as we step north of Monument Butte, we step out of the historic area that’s been drilled and water flooded and we continue to enjoy great success. But as we do that, we get a little deeper in the geologic section. We have a little bit more pressure behind it and we’re probably stepping into a little bit more of a fractioning system. So, yes, we do see improved characteristics.
As far as the 25% reference is probably one where we can say that we have assessed that acreage position and it’s statistical. And we can have high quality or high confidence in our predictions in recoveries on a mean - from a mean standpoint. We have stepped out and drilled some step-out wells with success. 
But I certainly wouldn’t describe the other 75% of the acreage position is being that we can statistically step out there and with high confidence. That’s going to be - I would anticipate in 2011 we would see more of those types of wells as we get more and more comfortable with what that acreage holds for us. But we’re just not quite there yet.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. Just one more thing on LOE for third quarter, it looks like it came in just about at the high end of guidance. Can you touch on what outside of the higher liquids content may have biased that towards the high end?
componenttext: Okay. Just one more thing on LOE for third quarter, it looks like it came in just about at the high end of guidance. Can you touch on what outside of the higher liquids content may have biased that towards the high end?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: As far as the recurring LOE if that’s what you’re looking at, it was a kind of a couple of things. As you recall, we - the liftings certainly did impact that to some degree and the fact that it - we had anticipated going into the quarter that we wou
componenttext:
As far as the recurring LOE if that’s what you’re looking at, it was a kind of a couple of things. 
As you recall, we - the liftings certainly did impact that to some degree and the fact that it - we had anticipated going into the quarter that we would be down more substantially in our international volumes due to the pipeline interruption when the guys got to field back on line quicker. 
With only four weeks delayed we had increased oil volumes and some of that ended up rolling in as far as the cost in the fourth quarter. That was a very just a marginal change certainly within guidance on the domestic piece of that.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. Thanks, guys.
componenttext: Okay, great. Thanks, guys.

componenttext: Okay, thank you. Operator?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Hi, thank you. This will be quick. Looking at the Gulf of Mexico for next year, what are you expecting for development cost in some of the projects you have queued up to come on line in the next few years, Dalmatian, Pyrenees, Axe?
componenttext: Hi, thank you. This will be quick. Looking at the Gulf of Mexico for next year, what are you expecting for development cost in some of the projects you have queued up to come on line in the next few years, Dalmatian, Pyrenees, Axe?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, John Jasek can answer that question.
componenttext: Well, John Jasek can answer that question.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Developing costs are - at currently we are expecting to stay within the guidance that we provided and we don’t see any significant increase in development costs going forward, and it’s due to obviously to the moratorium and the cost of goods and servi
componenttext: Developing costs are - at currently we are expecting to stay within the guidance that we provided and we don’t see any significant increase in development costs going forward, and it’s due to obviously to the moratorium and the cost of goods and services and the supply that's out there. So it’s pretty much as normal and no significant changes one way or the other going forward.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And what are you looking at for new drilling next year, any thoughts there yet?
componenttext: And what are you looking at for new drilling next year, any thoughts there yet?

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think it’s too early for us to discuss drilling for 2011. As we discussed earlier, we are in the process of understanding the wealth of regulations and new requirements coming forth from the BOEMR and that we will evaluate and read and react and proce
componenttext: I think it’s too early for us to discuss drilling for 2011. As we discussed earlier, we are in the process of understanding the wealth of regulations and new requirements coming forth from the BOEMR and that we will evaluate and read and react and proceed appropriately going forward.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: All right, well, thanks very much. Appreciate it.
componenttext: All right, well, thanks very much. Appreciate it.

headline: Newfield Exploration Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much, Rich. I guess assuming there are no further questions, we’d like to thank all of you for your time and interest at Newfield. We look forward to visiting with you on our next call and full-year results for 2010 and a little bit more
componenttext: Thank you very much, Rich. I guess assuming there are no further questions, we’d like to thank all of you for your time and interest at Newfield. We look forward to visiting with you on our next call and full-year results for 2010 and a little bit more color for our final game plan on 2011. Well, thank you, and let’s have a good quarter.
